—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat,-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

That we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring to a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That it be recognised the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner Bill is a public, legal acknowledgment that Australians who are non-aboriginal do not have sovereignty in their own country.

2. That the Australian people are opposed to the idea of a treaty, compact of makarrata between the Australian people who are non-aboriginal and those who are aboriginal, and the Government has no mandate or authority to pursue it.
3. That the proposed legislation and treaty
will damage Australia's position under international law and in any conflict,
will cause distrust and conflict between our aboriginal population (1%) and the non-aboriginal population (99%),
will extend aboriginal land rights, contrary to the wishes of the Australian people,
will not be acceptable to the aboriginal people themselves
will solve none of the problems of aboriginal people who need housing, health services, education and employment.

That therefore, the Senate reject absolutely the announced proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, and the negotiation of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Commonwealth and aboriginal people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and and Senators of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the film ``The Last Temptation of Christ'' portrays Our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ in a blasphemous and offensive way and is calculated to outrage the feelings of Christians.

2. That the decision of the Film Censorship Board to allow the importation of the film and to classify the Film with an ``R'' classification, rather than banning it, shows that the Film Censorship Board has failed in its statutory duty.
3. That in failing to exercise his powers and ban the Film the Attorney General has, as with his failure to band the film Hail Mary in 1986, failed in his duty to the people of Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will express its lack of confidence in the Attorney-General and the Film Censorship Board and pass laws which will ensure that no more blasphemous or offensive films will be permitted to be imported and/or screened in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What order of tax cuts can the economy afford next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The order of tax cuts which can be afforded next year is essentially a matter for further consideration and negotiation. I refer Senator Chaney, for example, to page 5 of the Treasurer's Budget Speech, where he says:

ANSWER.PARA: Tax cuts will then be paid from 1 July 1989.
These arrangements will underpin the wage decision recently handed down from the Arbitration Commission and open the way for both higher real incomes and lower real labour costs.
As the Government has stated previously, the size of the tax cuts to be provided will be dependent on wages growth during 1988-89 and the quality of the wage/tax trade-off to be negotiated.

They are some of the parameters for consideration of tax cuts next year. At the appropriate time, after those negotiations and further consideration have taken place, the Treasurer will make an announcement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training: How many jobs have been created by the Hawke Labor Government since it came to office in March 1983? How has that figure been achieved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a seasonally adjusted basis-although if one takes the original figures the gap between the two is not significantly different-6,265,000 people were in employment when this Government took office. On the September figures, again on a seasonally adjusted basis, that figure had increased to 7,408,000, an increase of some 1,143,000. In other words, since this Government took office more than 1.1 million additional people are in jobs. I was also asked how this had been achieved. It has been achieved under this Government's sound economic management; in particular, in a sustained period of economic growth averaging around 4 per cent over the last five financial years. An important component of that was a correction of the wages explosion that took place in 1981 and 1982, when wages increased by 13 per cent and 14 per cent respectively under the economic policies of the former Government presided over by the former Treasurer, now the Leader of the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: The correction of that wages explosion implied a decline in real wages, but that was offset by an increase in the number of people employed of more than 1.1 million. As I explained to the Senate last week, notwithstanding the fact that there has been a decline in average real wages, household disposable income per capita has increased. If anyone wants to read a well put together and independent analysis of those figures, I suggest that he or she read the article written by Ross Gittins and published in the Sydney Morning Herald last Saturday.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to announcements this morning by North Broken Hill Holdings Ltd and Noranda Forests Inc. of Canada that they are to develop a pulp mill in Tasmania. Could the Minister indicate what the future implications are of this development for Australia's balance of payments and employment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. Although he is a Western Australian, I know that he has long taken an interest in the well-being of the Tasmanian and Australian economies. The project is not just of importance for the Tasmanian economy; it is a project of national significance. At $1 billion, this project is the largest single investment in manufacturing in Australia ever made by private industry. It is not just the size of the investment or the fact that this will be about the biggest pulp mill in the world that is important. Of more significance is that the project is aimed at adding value to raw materials: 1.8 million tonnes of timber will now be processed into 440,000 tonnes of pulp for use in paper production, rather than being exported as wood chips.

ANSWER.PARA: Imports of pulp in 1987-88 were $224m, and a proportion of the output of the mill will replace these imports, which have been growing steadily in recent years. More importantly, about 90 per cent of the output of the mill will be for the export market. These exports will mean a net annual addition to our balance of payments of about $300m in 1988 prices. It is expected that some 2,400 direct and indirect jobs will be created during the construction phase and that the employment increase will settle at over 700 new jobs in Tasmania. At least 60 per cent of the plant and machinery required by the project will be sourced in Australia and it is expected that there will significant flow-on effects to manufacturing firms Australia-wide.

—Senator Haines's question is very detailed. I will refer it to the Minister and make a reply in due course.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the current political situation in Fiji. What is the Government's reaction to the reported threat by Major-General Rabuka to withdraw the licences of Australian banks currently operating in Fiji?

—I am aware of the press account in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning of an interview between Major-General Rabuka and a Fijian student in which the general is reported to have made reference to the possible closure of Australian banking operations in Fiji. At this stage I have received no official confirmation of this report and I will seek some clarification of it. May I say, however, that at no time during my recent visit to Fiji was any such possibility raised with me by Prime Minister Mara or any other member of his Cabinet. Moreover, I would not expect any such course of action to be pursued because it is so obviously counterproductive to the interests of Fiji in achieving economic recovery. I would have thought that all members of the Fijian Government, including Major-General Rabuka, were acutely aware by now of the impact on Fiji of a loss of business and investor confidence of the kind which occurred last year. There is obviously no better way to destroy that than to put at risk key elements in the nation's banking and financial institutions in the way that apparently has been floated.

—That is a different question.

—That is a different question. I do not know that it is actually supplementary. I guess that that is self-evident.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training seen reports that the Tasmanian Premier, Robin Gray, is in Sydney promoting Tasmania as a destination, not just for a holiday, but to live and work? How does Tasmania rank among the States as an employment provider?

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer the question to the Minister. —I ask the Minister for Consumer Affairs to explain the circumstances which led to his press release of 22 September 1988 regarding a recall of Neroa condoms, which are a therapeutic device. Has the Government taken any action further to the press release to ensure that consumers are protected from these defective condoms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank not only Senator Zakharov for raising this question but also Senator Messner for the competent way in which he has handled the problem that the Government faced with this particular brand of condom. The Trade Practices Act provides for a mandatory recall of unsafe consumer products. By matter of course the Government's approach in these matters is to take that action if there has not been satisfactory voluntary recall action taken by the supplier. As Minister for Consumer Affairs, I have authority over that particular part of the Act. It also has to be made clear that, in issuing instructions and issuing recall orders under the Act, I act in consultation with my colleague the Minister for Health.

ANSWER.PARA: In this instance we had a breach of a therapeutic goods order, Australian standard 1919. After consultation with the Minister for Health it was apparent that the Government had to take some sort of action. The condoms involved were ones that had been tested on a number of occasions, particularly by the Department of Health personnel as well as by an organisation acting for the University of Sydney. In the first instance we found that the condoms had the worst failure rate ever recorded by the Department of Health in having 33 out of 315 leaking when the allowable limit is seven. In respect of the second series of tests conducted by Enersol Consulting Engineers for the University of Sydney we found that the burstage tests in August this year indicated 37 condoms bursting out of a batch of 200. Both these failure rates were far in excess of the allowable limit. As a consequence, discussions eventuated with the supplier company to ensure that consumers were protected from such defective articles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you write a learned paper on the subject.

—I am not writing a letter about this; this matter affects quite a number of people. The Government, having realised that, is attempting to ensure that as much publicity as possible is given to the issue. In recent days, after consultation with the suppliers involved, we had a satisfactory result in that the voluntary recall was advertised in a number of newspapers last Friday. I thank Senator Messner for his cooperation in achieving such a result. Suppliers and retailers have been asked to return these condoms to the particular company involved, Neo Lux Corp Pty Ltd, which is based in South Australia, in order to obtain a refund. I take this opportunity to advise consumers generally that they also have that same right.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION LEGISLATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. —Has the Minister for Resources seen recent press reports of the opening of the first new gold mine in Ballarat in 70 years? How does this square with the dire predictions of some sections of the gold industry that the Government's decision to introduce a corporate tax on gold will lead to closures and a big downturn in the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports, which I think were dated 13 October, of a new gold mine opening in Ballarat. The heading in the Age was, `New Ballarat gold mine to be the first in 70 years'; the Sydney Morning Herald headline read, `Ballarat prepares for a new gold rush'; and the Melbourne Sun ran a headline which read, `Gold rush days return to Ballarat'. The company Ballarat Goldfields Ltd has announced that it is going to push ahead with a $15m exploration and development program. It has pegged a strip five kilometres long and half a kilometre wide in Ballarat East goldfields. It intends to sink a shaft 300 metres deep and then drive 500 metres westward to get under the Sovereign Hill tourist park and there exploit what it regards as a very productive gold ore body. It is, of course, an historic area in Ballarat. The Eastern Ballarat goldfield has produced since 1918 over one million ounces of gold, and further work will obviously add to that product figure.

ANSWER.PARA: This is an important announcement. It comes after the May economic statement in which the Government announced that it would extend normal company taxation to gold mining companies. Australia has seen a resurgence in gold production. In 1980 we produced 18 tonnes of gold. In 1987 that had gone to 110 tonnes, in 1987-88 to 127 tonnes, and the projections are for our production to increase, peaking in 1990. This year 20 new gold mines have been announced; two major mines in Western Australia, two major gold mines in Queensland and one major new gold mine in the Northern Territory. Ten of those 20 were announced after the May economic statement. We expect by the end of this year that a further 30 will be announced, including three further new major gold mines in Western Australia, a major gold mine in the Northern Territory and, of course, the Olympic Dam project will come on, which is a mixed mineral mine but is a significant gold resource in its own right. That will add 1.5 million ounces to Australian production. It will equal a capital investment in gold mining of $1.5 billion, if you exclude the half million dollars invested in the Olympic Dam which, as I have said, is a gold, copper and uranium deposit.

There have been some very minor effects of the October 1987 stock market crash, which has caused some rationalisation in the gold mining area, but there have been no significant closures of any gold resource at all in Australia since the announcement in May of the Treasurer's intention to include gold in the normal taxation regime. I believe the figures make it quite clear that the proposal to extend normal company tax-and not this nebulous term that promoters of the campaign against this tax call `gold tax'; it is a company tax, not a gold tax-is no deterrent and investment in this area is quite strong. The figures speak for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Education Services. Does the Minister recognise the important contribution that volunteers make to the community at large and the important role that organisations such as the Volunteer Centre of New South Wales play in the delivery of services to those in need? Does the Minister realise that the planned replacement of the community volunteer program by the Skillshare program will mean that the Parramatta Office of the Volunteer Centre, which services three-quarters of a million people in the west of Sydney and is totally funded by Federal Government funding, is threatened with closure because the funding of $67,000 is to be stopped? If the Minister does acknowledge the important contribution that volunteers make to the Australian economy, will he seek to have the decision to discontinue the funding of the community volunteer program reversed?

—Not surprisingly, I am not familiar with all the details of the large number of programs run within the Department of Employment, Education and Training. I did not know that the particular centre that was named is likely to close. I will refer the question to Mr Dawkins to supply an answer.

—I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: In view of the recent encouraging signs of more liberal thinking on the part of the Soviet Union leadership, what is the Government's policy now on the aspirations of the Baltic nations towards self-government and eventual self-determination?

—The Government has always had considerable sympathy for the position of the Baltic states. I think I would prefer, given the sensitivity of that issue, not to say more upon it until I have considered carefully the implications of the activity that is there occurring at the moment.
—Refer it to Hawke.
—Refer it to somebody for an answer.
—I will give a more considered answer when I have had an opportunity to consider the implications of current events in the Baltic states and the likely reaction of the Soviet Government to them.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Justice to various media reports about the National Committee on Violence. As this is a joint Federal and State initiative, can the Minister give some details about its terms of reference, and whether they are sufficiently flexible to handle the various issues involved?
—Why don't you do something positive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McGauran has interjected, even before I have given an answer. I believe the setting up of this particular committee, on the instructions of the Prime Minister, the Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, is a very useful response to a growing anxiety in the Australian community about the level of violence, which appears to be exacerbated and expressed, of course, in some very violent crimes that get great notoriety, but may themselves be only an expression of an increase in violence which is affecting many sectors of society. We know of domestic violence, of course, and the particular impact that has on women. We know of the general violence associated with drunken hooliganism. We know of the aura of violence that surrounds some streets and parts of cities and makes them unsafe, in the view of many citizens, for them to enjoy recreation and even just go to work or about their normal business without fear or anxiety.

ANSWER.PARA: It is to this general question of violence and the underlying causes which this Committee will address itself-this National Committee, set up, as I say, as a result of the determination of the Prime Minister, the Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory to try to unravel what underlies the violence of which I speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you leaving out videos?

—We are not leaving out anything. I always regret it when I answer Senator Walters's interjection because it gets into Hansard. Nevertheless, we are not leaving anything out. In fact, one of the points made by the Premiers at the summit on gun and other violence held late last year was precisely the impact that the media, in its various forms, might have on the inculcation of an attitude, a point of view, or a tendency in people to an early resort to violence to solve disputes. The whole question of media violence-the mass media in particular, including motion pictures and videotape recordings-will be looked at. It will not be a committee, I hope, that will duplicate the very valuable work done by committees such as the parliamentary committees which have examined video tapes in particular. It will not duplicate, for example, precisely in the same way, investigations being undertaken by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in respect of the broadcasting of violent material, particularly through the television media.

ANSWER.PARA: I think, without duplicating many valuable inquiries that have been undertaken, nevertheless the aspect that the honourable senator raised by interjection is something that, of course, the Committee will have to look at. Not only will it look at the state of violent crime in Australia at the moment; it will also try to look at the underlying social, economic, psychological and other factors that may give rise to this changing climate, as it is perceived by many Australians. The question of alcohol abuse and abuse of other drugs with respect to violence is, of course, an important matter that the Committee will be looking at, amongst many others. Not only will the Committee be looking at the question of those who offend by violent activity, but the question of the impact on victims of violence will also be part of its terms of reference, because the very traumatic effect of violent assault on a person is something that the community has to be, and is, aware of, which will, no doubt, lead to cries for more support and assistance for victims of violence; and that is something the Committee will be examining.

This Committee, under the chairmanship of Professor Duncan Chappell, who is the Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology, will not be an academic-oriented committee. It will commission research reports, of course. It will also visit every Australian capital-that is budgeted for-and the purpose of visiting those capitals is to conduct workshops and to listen to those persons in the community, individuals and groups, who have a point of view they wish to put. I am sure that listening to the community will prove to be a very important part of the role of the Committee as it makes its recommendations known.

It has been asked to report by 31 December 1989; but, if along the way the Committee wishes to put forward an interim report or reports in order to enable policy makers to deal with particular aspects about which the Committee feels confident enough to make recommendations, even though the full report has not been completed, it may do so. In this way I believe that it will be a very practical committee and will fulfil the expectations of the Prime Minister, the Premiers and the Chief Minister, and thereby of the community.

I believe that it will be a very useful response to the phenomenon in which Senator McGauran, as a Victorian and as a resident of Melbourne, I take it-even though he represents the National Party-would be very interested because of the eruption of crimes of violence in that city. Those crimes may be attributed to deranged minds or to the cold malice of criminal minds, but they may simply be expressions of a more general phenomenon which the Australian community must try to understand as we try to create a better society for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. A few months ago a new computerised system, based in Canberra, was introduced supposedly to streamline payment of salaries and allowances to Commonwealth employees. Is the Minister aware that this system is failing, with some employees waiting many weeks to collect travelling allowances? In other words, they are digging into their own pockets to work for the Government. One of my own staff is still awaiting travelling allowances dating back to July; another waited seven weeks for a pay cheque. The Administrative Services staff in Queensland are snowed under with complaints. Why has this happened and what steps will be taken to remedy the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Until halfway through Question Time I was not aware that the facts alluded to by Senator Sheil were in existence. I will have that matter investigated and get him a response. We would regard it as intolerable for people to be kept waiting for long periods for either their pay or their travelling allowances. It must be, I assume, relatively unique to Queensland because I have not had complaints from elsewhere. I will try to get a response before the end of Question Time or, if not, by tomorrow.

—Has the Minister for Finance noticed that Queensland was the only mainland State to record an increase in unemployment in September? Was the Queensland jobless rate at the end of September 8.2 per cent compared with the national figure of 7 per cent? Are these figures for Queensland alarming, especially given the imminent closure of Expo and the loss of jobs associated with Expo?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the figures in front of me, but the figures quoted by Senator Colston seem to me to be of the right order of magnitude and therefore, I think, probably correct-and the fact that Senator Colston mentioned them almost guarantees that they are correct. I was asked whether I was surprised. Well, I am not particularly surprised, because Queensland has had a very dismal employment record over a very long period.

ANSWER.PARA: The National Party Government, supported by Senator Stone, has for many years tried to explain away the facts by saying that people are coming to Queensland because they know that it is the State of opportunity and the State of good clean government-as the Fitzgerald commission has rather dramatically revealed! But the last time I looked at these figures I noted that in the case of people in the prime working age group there had been a net emigration from Queensland over a 12-month period of some 44,000, so, indeed, people had voted with their feet. Had they not voted with their feet, the unemployment rate recorded in Queensland would have been even higher.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. In view of the Government's commitment to women's health, as outlined in the National Agenda for Women, and in view of medical opinions that deaths from breast cancer could be halved, saving the lives of up to 1,100 Australian women a year if Australia had a high quality national screening service, can the Minister explain why Medicare benefits are not payable for mammograms except where women have symptoms of malignancy or a family history of breast cancer?

—The national policy on women's health is in the process of being developed by Ms Liza Newby. It has been completed and it is now with the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett. This issue, along with a number of others related to women's health, has been raised in extensive consultations that Ms Newby has had around Australia. I am not in a position to respond directly to Senator Patterson's question other than to acknowledge that this issue has been raised consistently by many women talking with Liza Newby. When the Government-and in particular Dr Blewett-has fully considered and had the opportunity to respond to the report I am sure that this and many other issues relating to women's health will be announced by Dr Blewett.

—Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware of anomalies existing in the current safety standards covering child restraints for motor vehicles? Is the Minister aware that these anomalies exempt some child restraints from needing to comply with the safety provisions of the Australian standard? What is the Government doing to rectify these anomalies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Childs raises a question of particular concern. There have been a number of anomalies in the legislation covering child restraints in motor vehicles. The anomaly which has been of particular concern to the Government is the one which, up to now, has not covered the situation of children under the age of six months. They have not been covered by mandatory safety standards because until recently there have not been available on the market goods that could be seen to comply with the standard that the Government wanted. The Government has taken action in this area-basically to cover this problem and to act in concert with State governments. From 1 January 1989 all child restraints, booster cushions and chairs will have to conform with the Government standard, as has been developed in consultation with industry. That applies to all those products which have been imported or manufactured on or after 1 January 1989. We have chosen that date to allow the industry some time to conform with the new standard. However, from 1 January 1990 all type `A' child restraints in motor vehicles will have to conform with the new standard.

ANSWER.PARA: Our intention has been to achieve the same degree of protection for young children under six months as is now available to those children over that age. When one looks at the Government's reponse to this problem, together with the action taken by State governments to ensure that children in motor vehicles must be carried in approved restraints-action has been taken in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and it is anticipated that other States will follow-one realises that we will soon have a regime of legislation which will ensure the utmost protection for children of all ages travelling in motor vehicles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following that erudite answer from the Minister for Consumer Affairs I ask him how many types of child restraint there are.

—I can answer that question by saying that there are three generic sorts of child restraints-child restraints, booster cushions and chairs. In terms of the actual numbers available, the Senate would probably appreciate Senator Baume putting that question on notice so that listing that sort of information would not take up the next 17 1/2 minutes of Question Time.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to the planned construction of 12 so-called Anzac frigates in Australia, with four of those ships to be purchased by New Zealand. Is the Government aware of widespread public opposition to the project in New Zealand? Is it correct that the Government has officially requested the New Zealand Government to approve the plan? Has the Government enlisted the aid of people outside the Government, including the Victorian Trades Hall Council Secretary, John Halfpenny, to convince New Zealand that it should join the project? Is the project economically dependent on New Zealand's participation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware that there is a vigorous public debate taking place in New Zealand on whether the New Zealand Government should participate in the program. It is not the only debate going on in New Zealand at the moment about Australian participation, but like all debates this one has two sides. Australia, however, is not a direct party to the debate and the decision on whether to participate is for the New Zealand Government alone. No commitment to buy any ships has been requested from the New Zealand Government. In any event, I would imagine that no commitment would be possible until all of the tenders had been properly evaluated. Asking New Zealand to commit now would be a forlorn request.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as enlisting the aid of others is concerned, many people have an interest in seeing the Anzac ship proposal prosper, and many have made their views known. Those views do not, however, necessarily represent the views of the Australian Government. As to whether New Zealand's participation is a prerequisite for the project going ahead, Australia will build at least eight Anzac ships whether or not New Zealand participates.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. What truth is there in the Sydney Morning Herald article of 15 October 1988 concerning the Australian National Maritime Museum which claims that the resources of the Museum, both financial and staffing, have been slashed; that the Museum will be forced to rely on volunteer attendants, which will jeopardise loans of valuable objects for display; and as a result of cost cutting the Museum's building now has no facilities for staff, storage or a library?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately much of the article to which Senator Aulich refers is woefully inadequate. Its inaccuracies are extraordinary, to say the least. The article gets it wrong in the first paragraph, so it did not waste much time in making mistakes, when it refers to funding for the Maritime Museum being slashed and its operational staffing reduced. In the current year's Budget the Museum has been allocated a total of $12.09m, an increase of about $500,000 on last year's appropriation. It has been allowed an average staffing level of 75 in the current year, an increase of 15 over last year's level. So the assertion in the article that staff has been reduced from 110 to 75 is pure fiction. The staffing allocation provides for 45 professional staff this year, including curatorial staff, and 33 after the Museum is opened. Senator Walsh, being one of the strongest supporters of the Museum, can verify what I have said.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the writer of the article has totally misunderstood the role of volunteer attendants. The suggestion that a collecting institution with such attendants would be unable to borrow valuable items is nonsense. There are collecting institutions all over the country which use voluntary attendants, and one does not have to go far to find them. The Australian National Gallery over the road is one such institution. It has no problem whatsoever in borrowing valuable items. So I am not quite sure where that suggestion comes from. Worthwhile museums around the world use this system, and this one is no exception.

Insofar as a drastic reduction of storage facilities is concerned, there was a reduction in size. That was a long time ago in the early planning stages of the facility at Darling Harbour. It was done primarily because more room needed to be given to public access to the site. Staff who are responsible for education and visitor services, management and security, et cetera will all be located on site. The library will be located in off-site accommodation, together with the professional and administrative staff. So the Government's commitments to the museum have been met and will continue to be met. I only wish that certain journalists would make decent inquiries before writing stupid articles.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications to reports that Australia Post is selling the names and addresses of more than 400,000 Expo season pass holders to businesses wishing to distribute junk mail. Will the Minister confirm these reports and inform the Senate whether it is true that businesses will be offered the lists at $124 per 1,000 names? How much revenue does Australia Post expect to raise through this gross invasion of privacy? Is this the only instance of the sale of lists of private names and addresses by Australia Post, or has it sold such lists on other occasions? Finally, how does the Government justify this abuse of information given to Australia Post in good faith by consumers?

—The information I have on this matter is to the following effect: besides an Australia Post promotional mailing, the mailing list was rented to only one other body, the Pakistan pavilion, for a promotion mailing limited to the south-eastern Queensland region. I am advised that Australia Post has undertaken not to make the list available to any other organisations pending resolution of this matter. I am advised that, prior to its own promotional mailing, Australia Post cleansed the list against the Australian Direct Mail Association list of those people not wishing to receive unsolicited material. In addition, the Australia Post mailing gave recipients the opportunity to advise by return mail through the free post mechanism if they did not want any further promotional offers to be sent to them. Of 240,000 items mailed by Australia Post, only 463 people have indicated that they do not wish to receive any further promotional material. Those names have now been removed from the mailing list.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PORTRAYAL OF WOMEN IN ADVERTISING: NATIONAL FORUM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. It relates to the first National Public Forum on the Portrayal of Women in Advertising, held in Sydney over the past weekend. Has the advertising industry supported this forum, and what results can Australian women expect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to comment on the tremendous success of the two-day forum that was conducted at the weekend. I am sure that Senator Puplick and Senator Hill, who attended the forum, enjoyed it. Senator Hill made an important contribution.
—What about my criticisms of the Government?

—Senator Hill was a little patronising at times, but I suppose we have to allow him to keep trying. The forum was a great success for a number of reasons. Firstly, there was an overwhelming number of participants. Over 600 people registered for the conference. I think all would agree that that is an indication of the concern that is felt in the Australian community about the way women are portrayed in advertising. Secondly, the advertising industry registered in large numbers. Fifty per cent of those who attended the conference represented the industry and 50 per cent represented women's organisations. Thirdly, an issue that was very important to the success of the forum was the range of women's organisations represented. Sometimes certain sections of the media and, dare I say, even some Opposition senators are inclined to say that this issue is one of concern to radical feminists and that it is not an issue of concern to Australian women generally. I have tried in this place and elsewhere to put that myth to rest. After the success of the forum--
—Honourable senators on this side do not say that at all.

—I am very pleased to hear that. I should not be acknowledging the honourable senator's interjection, as Senator Tate pointed out earlier. It is certainly true that a very diverse group of women's organisations were represented. They were able to sit down with the members of the industry, debate the issues of concern and work out constructive ways to improve self-regulation. I emphasise this for Senator Vanstone's benefit because she has spoken to me about her views in relation to self-regulation. There are ways in which the industry can certainly lift its game and improve the way in which advertisers are portraying women in the media.

ANSWER.PARA: There were two major outcomes from the forum. First, we will be establishing a task force that will involve the community, government and industry representatives to look at ways of improving the way in which women are portrayed in the media and educating the industry itself. It was important to note the way a large number of women working in the industry were quietly critical of the way the industry itself has not been willing to change in the past. Secondly, there will probably be some form of media watch organisation, a non-government organisation modelled on the Canadian line of monitoring the way in which the industry is responding. So all in all-I thank Senator Giles for her participation and contribution to the forum-it was a great success. It vindicated the research that we have done and it certainly vindicated the fact that 28 per cent of Australian women contacted during our national consultations were right when they said, `this is an issue of concern that we would like the Government to address'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer the Minister to the decision by the Films Board of Review to overturn the decision of the Chief Censor, Mr Dickie, to classify the film The Last Temptation of Christ as R restricted and instead to give it an M mature audience rating. In the light of the fact that people of any age will now be permitted to view a film which is clearly blasphemous and offends many Australian Christians, what steps will the Attorney-General take to ensure, first, that films of this nature in future will have to satisfy a much more rigorous test before being classified for release and, secondly, that the Films Board of Review is impelled to seek the views of interested parties in the same way as the Chief Censor did?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Films Board of Review made the decision to uphold an appeal from the original decision of the Film Censorship Board. I am trying to get that exactly correct because it is quite untrue to simply put forward, as Senator Watson did in his question, that somehow the Films Board of Review overrode the Chief Censor, Mr John Dickie. Mr Dickie is only one of several members of the Film Censorship Board. I make the point that even within that body the decision to give an `R' rating to that particular film, The Last Temptation of Christ, was indeed by a majority. There was a split view within that particular group of Australians appointed for that task as to whether indeed the correct classification for this particular film was R or M.

ANSWER.PARA: Once again when the matter went to the Films Board of Review there was a split decision. In that situation it is quite apparent that this matter of controversy is not easily resolved and certainly not by a simple assertion that the film was clearly blasphemous, the term used in Senator Watson's question. It is a very difficult matter of assessment and judgment. Different views were formed by both those bodies. In the end, the majority of members of the appellate tribunal came to the conclusion that the film could be made available under the M classification.

I do not believe that in this situation more rigorous testing is required. What was done was done by properly constituted bodies and is an example of the very difficult task which society gives them. I believe that they discharged their task very competently.

Whether Senator Watson or I, had we been members of that board or review panel, would have come to the same conclusion is another matter. It is certainly not clear from what one can read in the press that all Christians would be of the view that this depiction of the humanity of Christ was blasphemous. Within the Christian community, as within the two bodies, including the appellate body that I have referred to, there is considerable difference of opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your opinion? You are the Minister.

—I have not seen the film. I have read extracts from the book. It seemed to me to be a very interesting portrayal of the humanity of Christ. All I am saying is that the properly constituted bodies have come to the conclusion that they have. It is not surprising that they have been as divided as is the general Christian community on this question. I believe that the decision is one which, as I say, was properly reached by them after proper consideration.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister believe that the film is a correct portrayal, according to normal Christian belief, of the life of Christ? Can the Film Classification Appeals Board be impelled to seek the views of interested parties in the same way as the Chief Censor did? Would the Minister insist on that procedure?

—I am not quite sure of the way in which the Films Board of Review works. I know that it receives submissions from the distributor or the producer of a film who is making the appeal. As to what other information it acquires in order fully to comprehend the likely impact of the showing of the film on various audiences, I am not quite sure how it draws on other points of view in coming to its determination. I will find out about that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time last week Senator Reid asked me a question about an alleged reduction in nutrition services because of staffing cuts in the Department of Community Services and Health. I am now in a position to add to the answer I gave on that occasion.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Community Services and Health is not reducing its priority for nutrition services. The nutrition services program is managed by the Health Advancement Division of the Department. Nutrition is one of the five priority areas nominated in the national better health program. It is therefore sensible to amalgamate the work of the nutrition section with better health planning and nutrition within that division. There will be some efficiencies resulting from the amalgamation, primarily in the area of general clerical support. The bringing together of better health activities in the nutrition area and the work of the nutrition section should lead to a more efficient and coordinated approach to the development of nutrition policies and programs within the Department.

The national better health program places a significant emphasis on data collection and evaluation. A number of the databases currently managed by the nutrition section provide essential information in relation to the nutritional status of Australians. The national better health program will emphasise a wide range of interventions to improved health which are targeted to specific at-risk groups. These require adequate data. Structural changes, such as influencing the kinds of food available in supermarkets, training for professionals and community development will also be emphasised. In summary, the proposed staff movements are essentially the result of organisational change to produce a more efficient bureaucracy while at the same time maintaining the Government's commitment to nutrition service.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Crichton-Browne on Friday last, 14 October, stated that I had crossed the floor and voted in opposition to the majority vote of my own party, the Australian Democrats, for political reasons. I find this an arrogant and a revealing statement.
—Order! Senator Jenkins, in a personal explanation you have to confine yourself to correcting any misstatement. You should not attack the motivation or the remarks of the person making the statement.

—I beg your pardon, Mr Deputy President. Senator Crichton-Browne may not be aware, but, unlike the Labor, Liberal and National parties, the Australian Democrat members of parliament have a conscience vote on every issue. In fact, we are under a moral obligation to actually represent our electorate as we see fit. In other words, we are in a position to be able to put the people whom we represent above party political considerations.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Is this a personal explanation? Senator Jenkins is not actually talking about actual mistakes or corrections.
—Order! So far I think Senator Jenkins has been in order, but I repeat that she must confine herself to showing where she has been misrepresented and correcting the misrepresentation.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. This is what I did when I voted against the majority of my party with regard to the disallowance of the export control ordinance on 15 December last year. Having spoken with individual farmers and representatives of farming organisations, I came to the conclusion that this particular legislation was not in the best interests of Western Australians. Indeed, I admired Senator Crichton-Browne's action and presumed that it was a matter of conscience when he asked that his dissension be noted to the meat and livestock legislation--

—Order! Senator Jenkins, you are getting wide of a personal explanation. Link your comments to the personal explanation. You have to show where you have been misrepresented and correct the misrepresentation. Explanations of reasons are not relevant to this type of explanation.

—Yes, Mr Deputy President. I believe I am being relevant to the point in question. I am stating that I admire the actions of those members of the Opposition when they crossed the floor in this place and in the other place which I presume also to be a matter of conscience. I have publicly stated as much. I repeat, Mr Deputy President, that on the occasions when I have voted in opposition to the majority of my party, the Australian Democrats, or deliberately abstained, it has been on sincere, conscientious grounds and in what I believed to be the best interests of the people of my electorate of Western Australia.
—by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. I am sorry that I have to refer to the same senator, Senator Crichton-Browne, who misrepresented me in this chamber on Friday, 14 October.
—Senator Vallentine, you understand that the same rules apply, that you cannot attack Senator Crichton-Browne, that you can just explain.

—Yes, I understand, Mr Deputy President. He said in the Senate on Friday that when I visited the USS Brewton in Albany last month I was given three caps by the commanding officer. Senator Crichton-Browne got his facts wrong. One cap was presented to me by the commanding officer. I need to clarify the situation that occurred. When that was presented to me I said to the commander, Craig Kennedy, `You realise that this is a very embarrassing gift for me. What am I meant to do with this?' He said, `You can wear it when gardening or do with it whatever you like. Would you like me to put it in a plain brown wrapper for you so that you won't be embarrassed when you walk off the ship wearing this cap?'
—At least he has a sense of humour.

—He does indeed. We had a very cordial exchange. I said to him, `No, a plain brown wrapper won't be necessary'. I told him what I was going to do. I was wearing this same jacket and I stuffed it up the jacket. I said, `I hope this won't be offensive to you, but I cannot wear this cap off this ship'. That is the situation. It was one cap and not three. Subsequently, I delivered to the commanding officer of the USS Brewton a badge in return, a reciprocal gift, which said, `Friendships not Warships'. That was the spirit in which the visit was conducted. It was a very cordial exchange. I think Senator Crichton-Browne ought to get his facts right before he opens his mouth in this place.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 October, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill brings to our notice the change in the Government's approach with the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT). It is well noted by all senators that the current Tribunal which is available to pensioners and social security beneficiaries generally does not have the force of law; in other words, it has no legislative backing but it provides recommendations to the Secretary to the Department of Social Security in the event of evidence being put to it for the reconsideration of decisions of the Department on social security matters. The force of the Government's Bill is to give the Appeals Tribunal legislative backing and to establish it as an independent determinative tribunal which is capable of making decisions in its own right. It will not continue, therefore, as a recommendatory body to the Secretary to the Department.

SPEECH.PARA: While this may be welcome, there are some difficulties with it, which I would like to come to later, but I observe first of all that the Liberal and National parties will not be opposing this Bill, but they will be moving an amendment to the second reading motion to take account of certain points which we would like to bring out in the course of this debate.

Let me observe too that the Appeals Tribunal, as it will be constituted when this Bill becomes law, will not be the final appeal body for social security beneficiaries and pensioners. It will in fact be a first step and will remain as that, because there will always exist a right for those beneficiaries and pensioners to continue their appeal in the light of dissatisfaction with the decision of the Tribunal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). As has been known to the Senate, the AAT has been established as a somewhat more legalistic body than some of the other tribunals that are established under the administrative law system in this country. This is particularly so in the matter of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. In previous times the SSAT, as a recommendatory body, has undertaken its role in an informal and largely easy to get on with manner and in such a way that social security beneficiaries can easily put their point of view in plain language to have their matters heard in a way that will enable them to obtain maximum justice from the persons sitting on the Tribunal. The Tribunal comprises somewhat lower level officers from within the Department of Social Security and does not, in the sense that I mentioned earlier, constitute a kind of legal tribunal in the form of a court or a body which, in formal sittings with wigs and gowns, hears points being made and evidence adduced by social security beneficiaries in what are in some ways quite frightening and intimidatory circumstances.

Turning to the substance of the Bill, let me draw attention to one or two points that have been concerning the Opposition on this matter. First and foremost, the Tribunal, as it has been constituted, reviews up to about 12,000 cases a year. That is a considerable number of issues being brought before it by beneficiaries and pensioners over that period. Clearly, this means it is a most significant body in assessing the concerns and individual complaints of beneficiaries in this country. In that sense, it is a valuable filter, if you like, of the complaints procedures that ought to be available to Australians under the laws applicable to social security.

It is interesting to note that, along with that rather large number of cases heard per annum, the rate of veto since 1979 has changed quite considerably. Let me just quote the figures for the Senate. Firstly, in 1978-79 there was a 28 per cent veto rate by the secretary of SSAT decisions. This rate fell dramatically to 6 per cent in 1979-80 but rose to 8 per cent the following year, settling at an average of around 12 per cent in the next four years. However, in 1985-86 this rose steeply to 28 per cent, and for the following six months, from the figures that we have available, has reached as high as 35 to 38 per cent. In those cases, of course, the appellant has always got the right to go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if a further appeal is warranted. However, it should be noted that that change has been occurring. Therefore, the attention of Parliament is drawn to the fact that there are varying circumstances arising apparently from the administration of the Department which are considerably worrying and of concern to pensioners and beneficiaries in this country. If one were to speculate, there seems to have been some concern back in 1985-86, for instance, that views the Tribunal was putting forward were quite at variance with the Department. We wonder, drawing conclusions from those statistics, whether there are changes of policy occurring within the Department of Social Security which are having significant effects upon the clients of the Department, which, as a result, may well be affecting the rights and circumstances of individual beneficiaries and pensioners, and which have not been properly brought to the attention of members of parliament before.

I suppose that, in trying to make the point that emerges from the statistics, I should observe that it seems that, if policy is being properly adhered to within the Department, as laid down by a Minister, the question arises as to whether it is being properly implemented in such a way that it is being accepted by the clients of the Department and whether that is now being reflected in these very substantial statistical changes over the last several years. That conflict, if you like, raises the question of whether the SSAT is a credible body. Certainly, the more it is at variance with the Department and with its Secretary in its previous role as a recommendatory body, one must wonder whether it is achieving its objectives. To that extent, there appears to be some logic in the Government's institution of the new basis, by way of legislative amendment, to ensure that there is a proper legal base for its operations and that, in fact, the SSAT will have power of determination rather than of recommendation in the future.

The Opposition's concern is that the question of ministerial responsibility for the quality of departmental decisions and the policies on which they are based should be very carefully weighed in the event of there having to be a proper system of administrative review. The Opposition has circulated to the Senate for consideration an amendment which expresses that view and which I now move:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate expresses its concern that, while there is a need for an effective system of administrative review, this should not be at the expense of Ministerial responsibility for the quality of departmental decisions and the policies upon which they must be based''.

It is clear that the SSAT with its new determinative powers will in some ways become a more judicial body, and one which might be subject to future concerns in regard to clients of the Department of Social Security. It is obvious that further appeal mechanisms are available to those clients. They can, after the SSAT has dealt with the matter, go to the AAT as we discussed earlier. But beyond that they are capable of taking their cases to the Federal Court, and ultimately to the High Court if a matter constitutes such a problem. It is interesting to note that there is no provision for legal costs for clients wishing to put their views to be met, but the SSAT will determine any reasonable travel and accommodation costs in future and any necessary medical examinations that may be required to be paid by the Commonwealth.

I understand that the SSAT will mostly retain its existing structure with three member panels headed by a national convener. It would aim to continue the practice of having part time members and members who do not necessarily have any kind of legal background. To observe independence the Department of Social Security departmental officers will be appointed full time members of the Tribunal and will not be departmental officers for the duration of their appointment. It is clear that there will not be a direct challenge to the existing informal character of the SSAT hearings, which is to be welcomed. It will not be bound by legal rules of evidence or notions of judicial procedure. Consequently, we believe that if that remains, so the major objection to any kind of change along the lines of what has emerged in this piece of legislation will not eventuate. As I said earlier, the Opposition does not oppose the second reading of this Bill. I have moved our amendment drawing attention to the Opposition's concerns about policy making and ministerial responsibility. Consequently, I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the Social Security (Review of Decisions) Bill 1988 and welcome the fact that the Opposition does not intend to oppose it. If I may comment briefly on the Opposition's amendment, I read the amendment when it was moved in the House of Representatives and it was in the same terms as that which we now have before us. The amendment struck me as meaningless nonsense-so much so that I suspect Senator Messner did not understand it either because he did not really make any attempt to explain it. Perhaps he could not explain what the Opposition was getting at in its amendment. The amendment says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an effective system of administrative review . . . should not be at the expense of ministerial responsibility for the quality of departmental decisions and the policies upon which they must be based.

The Bill itself sets out a better process of departmental review of decisions. That should be acknowledged and welcomed as improving the quality of departmental decisions. In regard to ministerial responsibility, the Minister and the Government take responsibility for the legislative changes introduced into the Parliament. This Bill also covers the guidelines to be provided to the Secretary to the Department and to the National Convener of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT) about the administration within social security. Again, I regard that as an important part of the improvement of ministerial responsibility because those guidelines are to be tabled in the Parliament. That process of openness makes the Minister responsible for those guidelines. Perhaps the Opposition is suggesting that there should be ministerial discretion for all sorts of individual social security decisions. That is one interpretation one could put on the amendment. If that is what is meant, the Opposition should say so and we should debate that properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course not.
—I am pleased to hear Senator Messner say that, but I wonder how one is supposed to interpret the reference in the amendment to ministerial responsibility for departmental decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Having dealt with the Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading, I wish to refer to some of the key aspects of the Bill of which I am particularly proud. The Social Security Appeals Tribunal was a major reform brought about by Bill Hayden as the Social Security Minister in the Whitlam Government, but since that time it has continued purely on the basis of ministerial direction. It has had no legislative basis. This Bill entrenches the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and its processes and this first level of appeal rights in statutory form. It is to commence on 1 November-that is, as soon as possible after the passing of this legislation.

I do not think it is the Opposition's total position, but I noticed Mr Connolly in the House of Representatives questioned whether there should be both this level of appeal rights and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). He appeared to doubt whether the additional level was justified. I believe that it is important for the rights of social security clients for there to be this informal level of appeal and of course now a determinative responsibility for the SSAT rather than purely recommendations to the Department. Until now there have been just recommendations; the Department has been able to overrule the Tribunal, and has often done so. There will be a great responsibility on the SSAT because it will be implementing decisions rather than purely making recommendations. I suspect that the Tribunal will take that little bit of extra care in its decisions in the knowledge that the Department will not be in a position to overrule, although the Department and the clients can appeal decisions further to the AAT.
I mentioned the informal level of appeal and this is set out in section 193 which refers to hearings being as informal as possible. I will read the relevant part of the new section:
(1) The Social Security Appeals Tribunal, in reviewing a decision:
(a) is not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence;
(b) shall act as speedily as a proper consideration of the review allows; and
(c) shall, in determining what a proper consideration of the review requires, have regard to the objective laid down by section 176.
That new section 176 uses the following terms:
The Social Security Appeals Tribunal shall, in carrying out its functions under this Act, pursue the objective of providing a mechanism of review that is fair, just, economical, informal and quick.
I strongly welcome those procedures and that objective. The streamlined consideration will ensure that people do not have to wait any longer than is necessary for a decision on their appeals.

The other procedure that is important to people's rights and ease of access to the Tribunal is the new section 179 which allows for an oral application by a client, including an oral application by telephone. Again, that is important for those clients who might have difficulty with forms or in creating a letter setting out their case. They can make a written application, they can go to an office of the Tribunal and make an oral application or they can ring up the Tribunal and make an oral application by telephone. Once again that is an important part of providing rights to social security clients. Another important aspect that will continue from the current procedure with the SSAT is that hearings will be in private and as informal as possible.

I emphasise that the Bill also gives improved legislative basis for the review of decisions by the Secretary to the Department and his or her delegates. Where there are decisions by lower level officers, there is a higher level of consideration within the Department before it necessarily gets to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal stage. I hope that by this process many cases can be properly decided in the clients' favour without the need to appeal to the SSAT. That is an important part of the Bill which should not be overlooked.

In certain circumstances there is also provision for payment to continue pending the appeal being heard-that is, where a client is dependent on a pension or benefit he or she may still be allowed to receive it while the appeal is being heard without having to survive on nothing as a result of the initial departmental decision. Both the client and the Department can appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if either is not satisfied with the Social Security Appeals Tribunal decision. A point of interest is that, despite this Bill setting up a new statutory authority instead of the non-statutory body that has existed, this is a savings measure due to the streamlined processing involved. There will be a lesser cost to the Department and overall an estimated saving of $2.8m this year and $5.4m in a full year.

I would like to refer to the fact that there has been an attempt to move towards some plain English drafting in our legislation which I very strongly welcome and I am sure many others in this place do as well. It was not altogether a successful attempt in that there was some backsliding from the original intent of having a plain English Bill, but some aspects survived the drafting process. I would point particularly to the novel situation whereby some of the headings to sections are in the form of questions as they might be in a departmental pamphlet designed to be read by clients or those assisting them. For instance, section 179 is headed `How should an application be made?'. Another refers to `What happens if the decision under review is varied while the application for review is still being heard?'; `Who are the parties to a review of a decision?'; `What happens initially when an application for review is received?' These are examples of having such headings in the form of questions rather than in less easily understandable terms of traditional drafting. The relevant section provides the answer to the question that is in the heading.

There are also some explanatory footnotes which are a bit unusual and provide cross-references to other sections of the legislation. For instance, after new section 196 there is a note which refers to another section which gives in a more plain English form an explanation of the relationship between section 196 and the other section. Section 205 and some of the following sections refer to the review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. There are some quite detailed notes at the end of most of the sections explaining the meaning of the relevant section of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act, referred to in this Bill. People do not necessarily have to go hunting for the other Act in order to know the purpose of the clause.

I emphasise too that the National Convener of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal is required to give an annual report to be tabled in each House. Again, that ensures that all of us know the procedures that have been followed and the statistics of the appeals. I expect the Convener will also be in a position to make suggestions about necessary changes in the Social Security Act arising out of hearings that have been held during the year.

I refer briefly to the comments on this Bill by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills because I think they deserve an answer. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee expressed some concern about clause 6 of this Bill providing inappropriate delegation of legislative power. It comments on the Minister's ability to issue guidelines or, as the relevant subsection says, to present a statement to the National Convener of the Tribunal and to the Secretary to the Department. Such statements are also required to be tabled in both Houses of Parliament within 15 sitting days to give some guidance about the administration of the Act. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee expressed some concern about asking the Department or the Tribunal to consider non-legislative policy statements by the Minister. It is important that the Minister have this ability to provide these open statements-nobody is suggesting they are secret guidelines-and all that is required of the Tribunal and of the Department is that they shall have regard to the statement in exercising powers under the principal Act. Again, relating back to the Opposition's amendment, this is an important part of the Minister and the Government taking some responsibility for the administration of the Act, and it is an important clause in the Bill.

The other matter on the Social Security Appeals Tribunal that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee referred to is the fact that the National Convener of the Tribunal is able to give directions to other members of the Tribunal. The Committee suggests that this could be undesirable interference with the independence of the Tribunal. I would reject that. I would have thought the national head of a statutory authority necessarily has to give directions on detailed administration by the other members of the Tribunal. I emphasise that the National Convener is part of the Tribunal; it is not as if he or she is separate from it. It is important that there be some degree of uniformity in decision-making by all the various panels of the Tribunal operating around the country. I do not think anyone would want tribunals going off in different directions without some form of coordination by the National Convener and the various presiding members.

In conclusion, I emphasise that the right of appeal is crucial to the fair administration of the social security system. It is a provision that was missing prior to 1975 but it has survived since then and it is now to be properly entrenched. We must remember that in a lot of cases we are talking about the basic income support of people, and an adverse departmental decision can be devastating. It is important that there be the ability to have a proper hearing of assertions by a client that a decision was wrong and not in accordance with the Act. I very much welcome this Bill. I congratulate the Minister, Mr Howe, on all the reforms he is steering through, and on this significant one in particular.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats senators, along with other honourable senators who have spoken in this debate and many in the community, do welcome the thrust of the Social Security (Review of Decisions) Bill 1988. We believe that making the Social Security Appeals Tribunal an independent, determinative tribunal and no longer merely a recommendatory tribunal with relation to the Department of Social Security is a step in the right direction. That is not to say that we approach this legislation without reservation. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) began his second reading speech by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill marks a new stage in social security administration in this country.
That is true to the extent I have just mentioned, but the Minister went on to say:
It is a further plank in the Government's social justice priority of achieving equality of legal rights for all.

Certainly the Democrats would agree that the legislation heads down that track, as indeed does much of the legislation in this and other areas which the Government is putting forward, but we would not put it any higher than that. It is heading down the right track but we do have some concerns about whether the legislation will achieve equality of legal rights for all. As well as that, obviously concerns have been expressed to us by people working in this area and particularly people who are working closely with social security recipients who need to use the Tribunal and whose needs are paramount in our considerations.

I draw attention to comments of the Welfare Rights Centre in Sydney which suggests, as we have, that it is essential that bringing determinative powers to the Tribunal does not mean that there is a loss in the very important informality and accessibility which have characterised the Social Security Appeals Tribunal review process over the past decade. The Welfare Rights Centre points out that the primary expertise of the Tribunal has been, and it suggests strongly that it should remain, in the finding and evaluation of the particular circumstances in each case, especially those which tend to get lost in the ordinary administrative process. The Welfare Rights Centre details the crucial features, from its point of view-and it represents clients-of the Tribunal which have enabled it to carry out this role. First, there is the informal and personal contact with the applicant at the hearing; second, the consideration of the appeal by a three-member panel with expertise and experience jointly in law, social welfare and departmental policy and practice; and third, the preservation of Tribunal independence and diversity through a strong emphasis on part time rather than full time members. We note, along with the Welfare Rights Centre, that it is intended that these very features be preserved.

Some aspects of the Bill make this intention clear, but there are concerns that perhaps the Bill is not quite adequate in this area. The Welfare Rights Centre has suggested that this legislation would be better if there were provisions which would, for instance, limit the number or proportion of full time members appointed, ensure that members with relevant skills and experience other than in law or departmental administration are appointed-that is, to bring in the community voice and the client voice; and to ensure that whenever possible individual appeal panels continue to be composed of a `legal', a welfare and a departmental member.
However, the Welfare Rights Centre makes a particular point in correspondence I have had with it:
Finally, we believe it is entirely inappropriate for decisions under sections 163 and 164 (compulsory obtaining of information by DSS) to be excluded from review.

For the information of the Senate, proposed section 178 of this legislation details those decisions which it is the intention of this legislation be not reviewable by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. The Welfare Rights Centre expresses particular concern about sections 163 and 164 of the Social Security Act. Honourable senators may well remember-although unfortunately I do not think many will-that these new sections were put in the legislation by the mini-Budget of 1987. These provisions apparently went unnoticed by most in this House, or were treated with a lack of concern by most in this House, and recently Senator Hill discovered during hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs inquiry into privacy, identity card and tax file number issues-and he subsequently made public statements to this effect-that this was a dreadful thing for the Senate to have done. I now remind the Senate, as I did Senator Hill, that the Democrats did attempt to see that something was done to get in the way of giving the Department of Social Security such widespread and draconian powers. However that request was unsuccessful, as have been many other enlightened actions attempted by the Australian Democrats in this area.

The Government, having put these measures in place, proposes that they should not now come under this legislation and be reviewable by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. The Welfare Rights Unit in Victoria, the sister organisation, if you like, of the Welfare Rights Centre, is also concerned with these issues. When we talk about sections 163 and 164 of the Social Security Act we are talking about extensive powers to intrude into and invade the lives of social security recipients. Given that all recipients of family allowance, a large number of families, come under this heading, this ought to be a matter of great concern to the community. Under the legislation, the Department has been granted the unfettered right to demand information from any social security recipient, any public servant, any person working for any government authority, State or Commonwealth, and any person associated with, or who might have information about, a social security recipient. The Department of Social Security can demand information about a social security recipient from virtually anybody in our community.
