The power relates to any information required, to quote from section 164 of the Act, `for the purposes of the Act'. Taken together with section 166, this allows the Department of Social Security to override privilege, thus constituting a total denial of the privacy of all social security recipients. Looking at it from the other side, social security recipients have limited access to information from the Department. At the same time, the Department was granted the right to divulge information, as well as to collect it, on-again to quote from the Act-`classes of cases when it is in the public interest'. Again, the Democrats believe that this ignores the rights of individuals.

It is these sections of the Act and their inherent imbalances of power which, it is proposed, should be excluded from the determinative review of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal to be implemented by this legislation. In the committee stage I will move on behalf of the Australian Democrats, and on behalf of everyone concerned about this matter, including those who are victims of it already, that these sections of the Act not be excluded from the provisions of this legislation.

These provisions, which were implemented in September 1987 subsequent to the May statement of that year, have been causing distress to a great many social security recipients. The Welfare Rights Unit in Victoria published a document entitled Myths and Realities: Investigations by Social Security Field Officers in May this year which documents some of the distress caused by this invasion of privacy. Given that privacy issues are soon to be a major feature of debate in both Houses of Parliament-or at least I hope they will be-I hope not only that the Government will consider seriously the amendments we will be proposing in the committee stage with direct reference to these sections of the Social Security Act, but also that all honourable senators will address their minds to the implications of privacy issues in the community.

The legislation has been looked at, as is the usual practice, by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. In its Alert Digest tabled in the Parliament last week a couple of concerns were expressed. Some people working in the community have expressed similar concerns to me with regard to proposed new section 17 of the legislation, which allows for the tabling of a policy statement by the Minister. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee was concerned that this was not an adequate procedure and has, as is its usual practice, drawn that to the attention of the Senate and also the attention of the Minister. A response from the Senate is not expected until the coming week. So on this issue the legislation is more or less in limbo. It is the view of the Australian Democrats that at the very least the statement, duly tabled, should have the status of being a disallowable instrument so that it is not only a statement tabled in the Parliament but also a statement about which the Parliament might do something.

There are several reasons for concern about this process, not the least of which is that it affects a sensitive area, social security-an increasingly sensitive area, given the general political and economic direction of the Government and the Opposition. We believe that this process leaves social security recipients very vulnerable. A Minister could make a policy statement, table it, give-as the legislation duly requires-a copy to the Secretary to the Department and to the National Convener of the Tribunal, and that is where the action would stop. A Minister for Social Security-I dare not suggest in this Government, but in a future government-could decide to implement a major policy change and the Parliament, other than through the process of attempting to gain some publicity through the information that was presented by its tabling in the Parliament, would not in any short space of time effectively be able to anything about it.

A government, pushed by a Treasurer who was determined to increase the Budget surplus yet more and who was running around the world handing over cheques to pay off debts before the blaze of flash bulbs and television cameras, could say, `We are spending too much money on widows' pensions; therefore, we will issue a policy edict which will affect the way these things are administered. We will let Parliament know but there will not be anything Parliament can do about it'. We believe that at the very least this process should be subject to the same potential action by the Parliament as are other instruments which are laid before it and which, through due process, are disallowable in the event that there is concern about them and that they do not have general community support. To make that possible, I shall be moving an amendment in the committee stage which I hope will get the attention of honourable senators, as it is an issue which has been drawn to the attention of the Senate by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

It has been drawn to my attention that proposed new section 17 allows for a potential time gap, so that even the information might not be generally available through tabling in the Parliament after a policy decision has been notified. In other words, a major policy change could take place at the beginning, say, of the winter recess and not be able to be tabled until the Parliament sat for the Budget session, quite a long period during which not even information would be available.

With the amendment that I am proposing that sort of situation would still be possible, as it is with all regulations that come before the Parliament. However, there would be the sanction on government that the measure could be disallowed once the Parliament did sit. Any cavalier approach by a Minister who decided to come up with a major policy change and trample over the potential of the Parliament to act would be stemmed by that process, as it is now. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, individual senators and people in the community often act on regulations and ordinances as they come before the Parliament. At the very least we believe that is what this legislation should do. As I have said, we will be moving an amendment in the committee stage to try to get some support for that kind of process in this legislation.

They are not the only concerns with this legislation which have been conveyed to us by people working with social security recipients. Indeed, the claim by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus), representing the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), that this legislation is bringing equity to all seems rather extravagant when one looks at some of the other concerns. One other concern that I am hoping to address by way of amendment is access to speedy hearings specifically within the terms of the legislation on the grounds of financial hardship. We are not satisfied that the legislation as it is currently written gives that access to individuals who need to go to the Tribunal.

Another area of concern relates to the substance of the legislation. Proposed section 178 outlines which sections of the principal Act will not be subject to review by the Tribunal. Another area of concern is that if section 168 is excluded we believe the Tribunal will not have determinative powers on the question of what is an effective stay of proceedings when someone is making an appeal. Currently, the Secretary can do that by way of continuation of payment. That discretion ought to be available to the Tribunal if it is indeed going to have equal status with the Secretary and the Department in this area. Again, that is one area in respect of which we will want to move an amendment in the committee stage.

I refer again to the Minister's somewhat extravagant statements in his second reading speech. There are aspects of this legislation which give us concern and on which we hope further action might improve matters. Another area of concern is proposed subsections 189 (2) and (3). We believe that if an oral submission is not made at the time which has been set there ought to be a second chance, for all kinds of reasons. The opportunity to make an oral submission may not be taken up, notice may not arrive because of mail strikes or an unexpected emergency may arise on the day. We should bear in mind that social security recipients are often people who do not have telephones or motor cars and are very dependent on services generally within the community. It is possible for an oral hearing to be missed. The legislation would be better if a second chance, so to speak, were given but at the same time we would not go further than that. After that second chance is given, it is certainly important that the Tribunal be able to go on and make its determination. However, we believe there needs to be that extra bit of leeway.

Perhaps one of the most disturbing aspects of this legislation, given that we accept and welcome the thrust of establishing an independent determinative status for the Tribunal, is the intention of the Government to exclude from review by the SSAT sections 163 and 164 of the Social Security Act. Those sections have recently been brought upon us and are sections against which we have spoken often and will continue to speak often. I am amazed that the Government should have taken this step and drawn attention again to those sections, which are causing people a great deal of concern.

It is very important that the Government address its mind not only to including them in this legislation as part of the review process, but also to amending the Act again to remove the odious aspects of those sections which are unnecessarily broad and vague. The phrase `for the purposes of the Act' should be much more detailed, succinct and clear. Words such as `where the information is sought specifically for the purpose of the payment of a pension, benefit or allowance' would give us a great deal more comfort if we are going to give these further powers to the Department.

Finally, we believe the guidelines for officers of the Department implementing those sections should be embodied in the schedule to the Act. Looking at the Welfare Rights Unit material which is before us and at other material which I hope other honourable senators have had brought to their attention, there is a need to tidy up this area and take into account the rights and privacy of social security recipients around Australia. This legislation is an advance but we have some concerns about it which we will be wanting to address in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last dozen or more years the various departments of the Public Service have taken the opportunity to create all sorts of appeals tribunals to which they can refer their decisions in an attempt to remove themselves from the rigours of our ordinary courts of law. The appeals tribunals are supposed to be independent and are given a veneer of independence, as the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT). They have been peopled by tame public servants, as this one is intended to be, or retired public servants or they are simply jobs for the boys. The concerns that have been expressed so far in this debate are quite real. For example, the Minister is allowed to give directives to the Tribunal and so is the National Convener. He can do that before, during or after a hearing has commenced. That could lead to an inappropriate delegation of legislative powers. Fears that have been expressed-I hope the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) will answer them-are the reason why the Opposition is moving its amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly on the surface the Social Security (Review of Decisions) Bill 1988 has its attractions. We are not opposing it. The Social Security Appeals Tribunal was brought into existence in 1975 to review the decisions of the Secretary to the Department of Social Security. Of course, it could only make recommendations to the Secretary for the Secretary to accept or reject. The whole idea of the Tribunal was that it would hear these cases in an informal setting. Now the Tribunal is to be given teeth so that it can actually make decisions.

There have been significant variations in the veto rate over the years before the introduction of this Bill. In 1978-79, 28 per cent of decisions were vetoed. The rate fell dramatically to 6 per cent in 1979-80. It rose again to 8 per cent and steeply in 1985-86 to 28 per cent. During the following six months the rejection rate reached 35 to 38 per cent. They are very significant figures. I might add that even if an appellant is upset by the decision of the Tribunal there still remains a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). That right existed before and will exist after the introduction of this Bill.

It is estimated that the Bill will save $2.8m in 1988-89 and $5.4m in 1989-90. The basis of the savings appears to be a saving on administrative costs due to a streamlining of procedures. The Minister made a statement predicting that the new processes will simplify appeals and remove the delays currently present while the Department considers the SSAT's recommendation.

There are two main provisions of the Bill: firstly, to provide for a rationalisation of the social security review process by establishing the Appeals Tribunal with the power to make decisions; and secondly, to renumber provisions of the Act. I have mentioned the inappropriate delegation of legislative power which is contained in proposed new sections 17 (1), 17 (2) and 17 (4). Under proposed new section 202 there could be a trespass on personal rights and liberties. That was noted earlier in the debate. Under this section, the National Convener can give general directions as to the procedure to be followed by the Tribunal in connection with the review of decisions. That detracts from the independence of the Tribunal. The National Convener also can give particular directions as to the procedure to be followed in connection with a particular review. These may be given at any time, either before or after the hearing of a review has commenced. That could be an unwelcome interference in the function of the Tribunal. As I have said, the Government has said that the legislation has as an objective `to provide a mechanism for review . . . that is fair, just, economical, informal and quick'. Whenever John Q. Public hears the Government saying words like that he had better watch out that he is not ripped off once again. However, I cannot see this Bill bringing about anything like that.

—It states `have regard to'.
—It does not. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Convener:
(a) may give general directions . . . to be followed . . . in connection with the review of decisions . . .
Words have meanings. The honourable senator had better go back and look at Alice in Wonderland again. He is in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is not giving directions, though.

—I was talking about the National Convener. Can the honourable senator not hear? He has an additional defect. However, I will not go on with him. No legal costs are to be met or even awarded by SSAT, but I see that it can determine reasonable travel and accommodation expenses. The SSAT will largely retain its existing structure. It has three-member panels, headed by this National Convener. It aims to have part time members and members who do not necessarily have a legal background. So it is continuing the informal nature of the previous Tribunal. To preserve its independence, the public servants who will people it will be seconded from the Department of Social Security. Nevertheless, they remain public servants. Although the public may not be appealing from Caesar to Caesar, they are certainly appealing from Caesar to Caesar's wife.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not opposing the Bill. There is a risk that the SSAT may become too judicial and lose its informal nature. It may become too complex for individuals, particularly if it becomes too judicial. We cite as an example the Administrative Appeals Tribunal itself, which suffers from both of those faults, and the recent and dubious decisions that have been made by the AAT on social security cases. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise at the end of the second reading debate to answer some of the points that have been made and to respond to the amendments that have been proposed by both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. To pick up on what Senator Sheil was saying about his fears about how the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT) is to continue its operation in the future, let me say that his concern is one shared not only by people on this side of the Parliament but also by the Government in general. Through the Social Security (Review of Decisions) Bill, we are trying to achieve a mixture of both ministerial responsibility and independent decision making which can retain the flexibility that has been very much part of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal's operations in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill has been drafted in consultation with the Welfare Rights Centre, a centre that Senator Powell has invoked for some of the amendments that she is putting up before the Senate this afternoon. I should at this stage make a couple of points about that because only too often governments are not prepared to consult with relevant bodies. In this instance the person who issued the summary of the Bill on behalf of the Welfare Rights Centre, Mr Craig Sahlin, was a member of the Social Security Advisory Council Legislation Working Group, a group which looked at the draft legislation as it was being developed by the Government. At that time, and even most recently when consultations took place with him about this Bill, he did not raise one of the matters in the statement dated 13 October of which he is the author. Where people do have an opportunity to participate in a consultative process, it is not just imperative for their own credibility but more particularly for the rights of their constituency to participate fully in those discussions. It is a pity that in this instance that was not done at an appropriate time.

In drafting this legislation the Government has attempted to overcome some of the structural problems that Senator Messner has talked about. It was also raised in the House of Representatives debate that we are giving reviewing officers statutory recognition. We are giving them autonomy. We are also giving the Social Security Appeals Tribunal determinative power-power which has been long wanting in that institution. As I said, this Bill has been drafted in consultation with welfare groups. In fact, the working group that oversaw much of the drafting was chaired by Terry Carney, who was quite often quoted by the Opposition in the House of Representatives as a critic of the pre-existing operation of the SSAT. So the Government has consulted widely and taken into consideration much of the criticism that has been raised about the operation of this area of decision making.

Senator Messner, in his contribution, mentioned figures relating to the number of Social Security Appeals Tribunal decisions that have been overturned by the Department. This Bill, of course, will in the future do away with that sort of problem. It should be noted that, even though the Opposition has been quoting figures such as a 12 per cent rejection rate in the four years from 1981, the actual rejection rate for the year 1987-88 is 14.8 per cent. So we do not have all that much of a discrepancy when one looks at the actual figures in this area. As I said, the Government is trying to streamline the process even further.

One objective that has been raised and one particular problem that I suppose is very much the point that governments have had to grapple with in this area for some time is that on the one hand one needs to have uniformity and a general approach to the whole area to ensure that people's rights are not different from one part of Australia to another, and on the other hand one needs to allow a certain degree of discretion to handle particular cases. I think the balance that has been struck in this legislation is such that it will allow the maximum opportunities to do that. On the one hand we have the Social Security Appeals Tribunal proceeding in a rather flexible way, in a much less formal way than any other mechanism, and on the other hand we have the final tier, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which acts in a much more formal way. Given a mix of both these institutions, I believe that the flexibility that is needed to handle problems in this area very expeditiously can be achieved.

Senator Powell raised a couple of points in terms of amendments that the Democrats will be moving in the committee stage. The first relates to the position as put forward by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, that there was some concern about whether a Minister should be able to direct the Tribunal in a manner which would be unacceptable under our system of legal rights. What has to be recognised in approaching this particular proposition of the Democrats is that what we have in this legislation is for the first time provision for ministerial and Government policy to be made public and to be tabled in the Parliament. I think that is very much an advance and an improvement, and one that should be recognised. To go one step further and make that policy disallowable by one or other chamber of the Parliament would, I think, cause major hold-ups and bottlenecks. Also, I do not think it would achieve the objective that Senator Powell is concerned about.

If we are concerned about government policy being in conformity with the law, then already there is a whole series of High Court decisions which ensure that tribunals such as the SSAT will not and should not take into consideration government policy that is outside the legal regime under which it is formulated. The decisions go back to 1965. The most recent was one of Mr Justice Brennan's in a case in 1979 where he made it clear that government policy should be followed only if it was lawful. I think when one takes into account the current legal structure of the Government and the operation of the tribunals, one can be satisfied that policy inconsistent with law passed by this Parliament will not be implemented by the SSAT.

We then go on to other provisions raised by Senator Powell and the removal-or the reinstitution, as the Democrats would like to call it-of the exercise of power under new sections 163 and 164 of the Act to SSAT scrutiny. New section 163 of the Act requires a claimant to notify changes of circumstances and new section 164 requires a person to answer questions and provide documents. I think one should look at these two specific provisions in the light of the fact that the Tribunal's role is-and I think is intended to be by the Parliament and I am sure by the organisations involved in this area-to review substantive decisions about a person's entitlement, not to supervise procedures of the Department of Social Security. We should also recognise that in this area the Ombudsman has some rights and powers and we in the Government think it is best to separate these two functions and allow both the Ombudsman and the SSAT to pursue their rightful roles in their respective areas.

A further Democrat amendment seeks to have under the ambit of the SSAT the operation of section 168a of the Social Security Act. This particular section relates to the power to continue payments pending appeals. I can see why Senator Powell is concerned about a beneficiary not having his payments under this particular provision suspended while he is going through an appeal process, but I do not think the problem she raises is as difficult or grave as she would have us believe. I am advised that even at the moment, in cases of urgency, a person can have his case deliberated upon and decided within seven to 14 days. Given the fact that if he were to have his payments suspended during that appeal process that urgency is increased, I would argue that his case for an expeditious hearing is being augmented as a consequence. People will get a decision in the area in which they basically want it, that is, the substantive position of their appeal, rather than in the intervening few weeks before they get a final conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a guarantee, I take it.

—In terms of guarantees, both Senator Messner and I have been in a position where we have had to rely on the goodwill of others, but I do say that even at the moment a person can have his case heard within seven to 14 days in urgent matters, and given the fact that we have over the last five years experienced somewhat of an increase in the unemployment area because of, should I say, the policies of the Government that went out in March 1983, then maybe in the future their position can be ameliorated.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, let me go back to the final point, which is that we do not accept the Opposition amendment to the second reading motion. What we have done here is to achieve a balance between on the one hand the exercise of ministerial discretion and on the other hand independent decision making by tribunals. Let me also go back to consultation. I think I might have mentioned that Craig Sahlin was consulted formally. In one sense, he was. Craig was in fact a member of the Social Security Advisory Council Legislation Working Group and as such was obviously consulted as a member of that working party in the processes leading up to the Bill. Going then to Senator Powell's amendments, I point out that with some goodwill on the part of the Welfare Rights Centre in New South Wales and also in Victoria some of the representatives can take a much more active role at the right time rather than leave it until the last moment.

(2) Page 2, clause 4, proposed subsection 17 (2), lines 21 to 25, leave out the proposed subsection, insert the following subsection:

These are the amendments suggested by me in the second reading debate. They pick up the concern about statements of government policy and what might be a more appropriate way for them to be conveyed and acted upon by both the community and the Parliament. In moving these amendments to clause 4 I would like to say that I thank the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) for his response to my speech at the second reading stage but I hope that in his response to my foreshadowing of these amendments he was not saying that if individuals or organisations are part of a consultative process with the Government-a process that the Australian Democrats heartily endorse, support and congratulate the Government on-this means that no subsequent adverse comments, however gentle or constructive, can be made by those people or organisations.

I know there has been a tradition of a gag on public servants, preventing them from making public statements on matters in their areas. I do not know a lot about it, for the only kind of public servant I have ever been was a teacher and that was before I was a politician. It is very hard to gag a teacher. Now that I am a politician it is impossible to gag me. I understand that that situation has applied in the past, but it has been somewhat relaxed and I think public servants are now perhaps able to make statements if the subject is not in their area. I hope the Minister was not saying in his foreshadowed response to these amendments that any community based individual or organisation might need to see itself operating under such a gag. I again commend the Government for its consultative processes, where they are in operation, but it is a fact that, where individuals or groups talk with other individuals and other groups in this community, an opinion expressed on one occasion may very well develop as a result of further consultations that they might have with people other than the Government. It is always sad when governments are elected and re-elected and suddenly get this feeling of being born to rule. Indeed, being quite serious for a moment, it is a matter of great concern that not just Craig Sahlin and the Welfare Rights Centre but other groups in the community with whom this Government consults-and I again commend the Government for that consultation-do feel subject to this type of constraint. I believe it is not appropriate that there be even a hint that non-government community based organisations are constrained by such consultations that have taken place on this Bill. Part of the process of this Parliament is to be able to act on government policy and policy statements. I certainly take the point the Minister for Consumer Affairs made with respect to perhaps another road to go down, but I do not agree that it is inappropriate for this House of Parliament or any other House of Parliament to take action to stem the tide of any government policy. We do it all the time with regulations introduced by government. I see no reason why that would not be an appropriate course in this case. Therefore, I have pursued the issue, although the Minister made, as I say, an interesting point on this matter. But the Australian Democrats still believe that, if major policy statements are going to be made in this area, they should come before Parliament in a manner which enables Parliament to act upon them, if it so desires.

Again I express some concern about the view expressed by the Minister that it is inappropriate for Parliament to act upon government policy decisions, because I would be most disturbed about it. I think governments need, hopefully for the foreseeable future, to take into account the fact that they will not always be able to get all their decisions through all houses of all parliaments. At least that will be the case so long as the Australian Democrats are here, and that is why people keep putting us here. I have moved these amendments to ensure proper review by the Senate of government policy decisions in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal and National parties will not be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendments. Might I say at the outset that one of the problems Senator Powell has presented the Committee with is that she has put forward the amendments without proper notice being given.

I asked the Clerk to see whether they were available, but they were not. That was the first I had heard of them. Certainly, if the Democrats are seeking support for them, one should have thought that their duty would be to at least advise other honourable senators about what they intended. They are not even prepared to tell us what they are to give us due time in which to consider them.

SPEECH.PARA: Leaving that aside, it just shows that perhaps Senator Powell, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, has rushed into print faster than she should have. If she were to succeed in having these amendments incorporated into law, we would have a situation in which indeed the decision of a Minister and a policy statement as such would be thrown into chaos by the possible disallowance by the Senate in respect of that matter, which could lead to all kinds of difficulties in the administration of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. At the very least, I should have thought that Senator Powell would have brought it to the attention of the Opposition that the Australian Democrats intended to move such substantive amendments, so that we could have given proper and deep consideration to how she might have applied such a theory which she is seeking to put into practice by such a quixotic method. Obviously, she has not thought it through and I am quite sure that her Party has not thought it through. As a result, the amendments do not have the support of the Liberal and National parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response, I refer to the Government's position as I indicated in my reply at the second reading stage. Just to make one final point with respect to these two amendments moved by Senator Powell, what the Committee has to remember is that we are talking about government policy as expressed by the Minister, not his actually directing the Tribunal. We are talking about the Tribunal having regard to government policy. When one takes into consideration the fact that we are only asking the Tribunal to take policy into account and also, as I said in my response at the second reading stage, the fact that the law as it now stands ensures that any policy outside the framework of the law need not be followed by any implementing or administering tribunal, I think the concerns Senator Powell and that the Welfare Rights Centre have are well and truly accommodated.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

`` `(2a) Where an applicant claims to be suffering from financial hardship and requests a speedy hearing for that reason, the National Convener shall take reasonable steps to ensure that the decision is reviewed as quickly as possible.'.''.

These amendments relate to two other concerns that we Democrats have about this legislation. Amendment No. 7 relates to changes to the process of the handing over of documents by the Department of Social Security and access to such documents. Given that the Social Security Appeals Tribunal currently receives the whole file of a person who has made an application, if only part of a file is sent applicants will have to have recourse to freedom of information applications. This would create unnecessary costs to government and delay the hearing of an appeal. We propose these amendments in an attempt to ensure that that does not happen.

Amendment No. 8 is an attempt to ensure that where someone claims to be suffering financial hardship a speedy review is available. We are not satisfied that the Bill as it stands covers this area. Currently, any person in financial hardship can apply for a quick hearing. We believe that the present proposal is much narrower. Once a quick appeal is granted, it can still take up to 3 1/2 weeks-as in a case recently brought to my attention-before the Tribunal reaches a determination. It is important that a quick hearing can be granted and we believe that these amendments are necessary to ensure that that is the case under this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I wish to say that we will not be supporting amendment No. 7. The insertion of the words `reasonably be considered' rather than the words `is considered by the Secretary' appears to us to introduce uncertainty in a situation where probably there is a need for very great certainty in the process that is being undertaken in the interests of the client of the Department. I am not convinced by Senator Powell that the amendment will bring any great benefit to the client.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of amendment No. 8, the Liberal and National parties are somewhat attracted to the idea put forward by Senator Powell, but in the light of our doubts about the wording of the amendment it is difficult to make what could be a meaningful change on the run in the fashion suggested. It would have assisted the Opposition a great deal if we had had the opportunity to look further into this amendment and consider it in greater depth. However, the Democrats apparently chose not to disclose their hand in time for that to occur.

—Unfortunately, that is news to us. We have shadow Ministers representing shadow Ministers in the Senate, and it is a pity that Senator Powell did not bring up the matter with us. Can the Minister give us some assurance that in the event of a need for a speedy hearing because of financial hardship due process will be properly considered? Can the Minister assure the Committee, given the limitations of the situation, that people will not be unduly ill-treated if this amendment is not enacted?

—I welcome even the tepidity of the Opposition's response to amendment No. 8. It gives some heart in terms of the possibility of getting some sort of enlightened approach to government legislation. The official Opposition in this place is supposed to be the Liberal and National parties, and people in the community with concerns, even people in the welfare sector, approach those parties. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

There is some degree of pressure on the Department to ensure that relevant material is provided to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's proposal seeks to streamline administration, and one must bear in mind that the Secretary's decision in these instances is reviewable in a number of circumstances. For instance, a beneficiary has rights under the freedom of information legislation which can be exercised, and the tribunal itself can request specific information. In fact, proposed section 191 allows the National Convener to ask the Secretary to provide information or a document which the Secretary has; so there is power in that regard. One also has the Ombudsman. If one is not satisfied with those three avenues, there are as many cases go further the powers of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the legal mechanisms available there. Therefore, this should not be seen as a sinister approach by big government.

I understand Senator Messner's statement that amendment No. 8 has some attraction; but the Democrats' amendment as it stands says that, where an applicant claims to be suffering from hardship, the Convener has to take reasonable steps to ensure that the decision is reviewed as quickly as possible.
