TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now starting to debate a Bill relating to the provision of certain equipment for Qantas Airways Ltd. In leading for the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, I declare at the outset that both parties will support this Bill, although we will move an amendment to the second reading motion. We regret very much that this Bill is necessary. The reason it is necessary is Qantas's acute lack of capital. That really can be sheeted home to this Government's five years of mismanagement of the whole aviation sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill sets out to give Government guarantees to Qantas for a very complex borrowing system, which I will examine later, for it to buy three Boeing 767-300 extended range passenger aircraft. Presumably, the reason that the Government has to act as guarantor for Qantas is that Qantas has such a very small capital base with respect to its borrowings that it has exceeded what people are prepared to lend it unless the Government guarantees it. This is a situation that should not exist in this day and age. The only reason we are locked into this situation is the absurd ideological position of the Government in not selling Qantas to private enterprise. The days are long past when governments have to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody in the Government cares about this. There is nobody on the Government side.

—Yes, no-one cares about this at all. It is interesting that Senator Sanders has commented on that; there is literally not a Government Minister in the chamber at the moment. There is not even the Whip here. It is quite astonishing. In all my 11 years in the Senate I have never seen a situation where there was not one member of the Government keeping the Senate. It is an inviolate rule that there is always a Minister, always a Whip and always about half a dozen government members in the chamber. I think it shows the contempt with which this Government treats the institution of Parliament in general and the matter of Qantas and the aviation sector that I was talking about a while ago. It is sad that these words of wisdom and gratuitous advice that I am prepared to offer to the Government without any fee at all are going to be lost on it.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to provide a guarantee for the purchase of three Boeing 767 extended range aircraft. These are a stretched version of the 200 series that Qantas operates at present. They carry 231 passengers as against the 208 passengers in the present 200 series. That will allow Qantas to put a first-class section into these aircraft. One of the criticisms of the existing 200 series Boeing 767 is that it does not have a first-class section. The 200 series aircraft have been very successful. They have really been great money spinners for Qantas. The ultimate test of a transport aircraft is whether one can make money out of it. The 200 series aircraft have been very efficient for two reasons. The first reason is that they have a great deal of systems redundancy built into them with the introduction of advanced avionic systems, solid state digital systems and duplication, triplication and even quadruplication systems. They start with inherently very reliable equipment which is backed up by alternative parallel systems so that if one fails the aircraft can still fly safely with a full complement of services on board. The operational experience of the systems in the 767-200 series has been exemplary. The aircraft look the same as the ones that Ansett Airlines of Australia operates but are really quite different under the skin.

The other great efficiency of these aircraft comes from their engine installation-they have a very fuel efficient engine. The aircraft fly high, higher than 747s. As I said before they have been great money spinners for Qantas. The other great advantage is that being roughly half the size of 747s, they allow Qantas to operate on routes where the traffic does not justify the employment of a full sized 747 aircraft, thereby giving Qantas a great deal of flexibility in the route structures that we need around the South Pacific and around the whole of the rim of the Pacific Ocean. The aircraft will enable Qantas to operate out of all the capital cities of Australia, for example, picking up small loads and going to places such as Singapore, Hong Kong and even Tokyo.

I cannot help but reflect on the speeches I made and the private conversations I had with Qantas through the last 10 years when that company was locked into one type of aircraft-Boeing 747s. I was saying both in private and in public that the airline needed to develop the flexibility that came from a mix of aircraft in the fleet. Ten years ago when Qantas was looking basically at long haul routes to Europe, Japan and North America the argument in favour of settling for one aircraft type was very persuasive. That certainly cut the supporting side greatly with crew training and maintenance spares holdings. It made the operation very much simpler and therefore much more attractive economically, but the penalty paid was a great deal of route inefficiency. One simply could not operate on the smaller routes and change the route structure very readily.

I said previously that this Bill has come about because of Qantas's acute shortage of capital. It is symptomatic of the Australian Labor Party that it does not understand anything about business. While it is in bed with big business, big unions and big government-the whole trinity of this present Hawke Labor regime-it still has not grasped the fundamental point about business. If one is to run a business successfully, even if one is going to be in business, two requirements have to be met. I see that Senator Maguire is taking note of that; as a budding economist he can write these words down. The first thing one must have is adequate capital. The second thing one must have is business acumen. All the business acumen in the world is of no use if one does not have an adequate financial base. Nothing works unless there is a certain amount of money in the kitty, to put it in the simplest form, because all the working capital cannot be borrowed. If all the working capital is borrowed, particularly at the high rates of interest that exist now, one cannot make a profit. Margins are too low to pay interest, make a profit and repay the money borrowed. The international airline business is as competitive as any other form of activity on earth. The Australian Labor Party does not understand that. It does not understand also that the way out of this problem is to sell the airline-to sell it to the Australian community, preferably first of all to the 13,000-odd Qantas employees, and raise capital in that way.
Earlier this year in the old Senate chamber we debated the Williamstown Dockyard employees Bill. I said in my speech:

. . . the general rule that I hold-I do not hold it dogmatically or ideologically-is that governments simply should not be in commercial operations if they can be operated by the private sector. The reasons for that are basic and fundamental.

I hold firmly to that belief. It is not the business of government to be in a commercial enterprise if that enterprise can be adequately run by private industry. The reason is that the Public Service simply does not have the expertise to make the commercial judgments that are the lifeblood of the day to day activities of industry. There is no training system in the Public Service to train executives for commercial enterprises. Nor can there be, because no system of reward and censure exists in the public sector. If one does well in the private sector one is rewarded, but if one does badly one is fired. No-one ever gets fired in the public sector. If people make a mess of a program, if they overspend on a program by $5m or $15m a year, they get promoted and get more staff so they can lose $20m the next year. The private field just cannot operate in that way.

In the past-150 years, 100 years and even 50 years ago-Australia was very short of capital. There was an acceptable argument for governments, with their better capital raising facilities, to involve themselves in the provision of basic utilities in the community, in the building of things that could not be built because of the shortage of capital. Of course that was how the Government got involved in Qantas. But those times have passed and private industry now can raise more capital than government can, and often can raise it cheaper, at better rates and in a much more convenient way. The dreadful position existing today of Qantas being starved of capital can be overcome by selling the airline and turning it over to private industry.

Clause 2 of the Bill guarantees $US235m for the purchase of three aircraft and their support equipment. But do not let anyone in this chamber think that that is the end of the business. On Thursday night of last week I attended an Estimates committee hearing dealing with the Department of Transport and Communications. I asked a question of Senator Gareth Evans, the immediate past Minister for Transport and Communications and the Minister in attendance at the time, about how Qantas was proposing to finance the purchase of 25 per cent of Air New Zealand. A Mr Phair, from Qantas, indicated that negotiations had not been completed. The Minister then said, in answer to my question:

I can answer that. The reality of the matter is that whatever the investment ultimately proves to be in Air New Zealand it will be substantially less than the capital cost of one new aircraft. That is against an environment of a major investment program-
this is the really critical point-
Over the next few years-
I interpret `few' to mean two or three-
something like $5 billion will be spent involving the potential purchase of 25 to 30 aircraft.

There it is, straight from the immediate past Minister: $5 billion is the capital requirement of Qantas in the next two to three years. Does anyone in this chamber think that Senator Tate, Senator Walsh, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or anyone else is going to gouge $5,000m in extra taxation from the Australian taxpayer, given the crippling rates of taxation we already bear, to keep Qantas competitive? One has only to state the proposition to see how completely absurd it is. The capital resources are no longer there in the public sector. We are being taken down this path because the Government is locked into the worst sort of ideological dogma. It is not game to take on the far Left, the Centre Left and any other part of the Left in the Labor Party and tell them a few of the basic facts of economic life. I will be interested to see where that $5 billion comes from if this Government survives-which I do not think it will. We are looking two or three years ahead, but I think this Government will be sitting on this side of the chamber within about 10 months.

The fact that Qantas has to get Government guarantees is not the only sign that Qantas is short of working capital. I have been a very faithful, strong and vocal supporter of Qantas both in private and publicly during my time in the Senate. But one has only to look at the airline today to see that it is desperately short of working capital in all sorts of ways. I recently flew to London, on to Washington and back across the Pacific. It was the first time for over two years that I had been such a considerable distance away from Australia. I was shocked at the standard of the Qantas aircraft I flew in. I regret very much to have to say that this airline, which once compared more than favourably with the other airlines of the world from a passenger point of view, is now not providing the service that other airlines are. The cabins of the aircraft are not as clean as they might be. The aircraft have a general run-down air about them. Far more seriously, aircraft are being dispatched down the line with a large number of maintenance defects, though these defects are said not to involve the safe operation of the aircraft.

Within the last two or three weeks there was an article in the Australian under the headline, `Qantas sends work to USA'. The article states that Qantas was short 110 licensed aircraft maintenance engineers. That is a huge number. The article goes on to say that Qantas will need an additional 700 to 800 engineers within 12 months just to cope with the work in hand. As a consequence of this, Qantas is going to send two 747 aircraft to the United States for routine maintenance. This is going to result in the loss of 40,000 man hours of work that could have been performed by the Australian work force and will cost the company $200m, which will add to our balance of payments problem.

The reason Qantas is in the position of not having these 110 licensed maintenance engineers is simply that the Government, with its ideological commitment to a centralised wage fixing program and the wage policy it is running, will not let Qantas meet the market. If Qantas could go to the market and hire licensed engineers at the going market rate instead of being stuck with what Mr Hawke, Senator Evans or Mr Willis think it should pay, it would not have a shortage of engineers. Then the aircraft would not be going out in the state they are.

I do not want to overemphasise the unserviceability of equipment on aircraft but on a number of the aircraft I flew on in the last month unserviceable equipment on board was reported and not fixed. Some of that equipment related to hoists for getting food up from the galley, and so far as I know none of it reflected on the safe operation of the aircraft. But as someone who has been involved in aviation for most of his life, has owned aircraft for over 20 years and has more than a passing knowledge of maintenance problems and practices with aircraft, I can state categorically that one cannot draw a theoretical line with an aircraft as to what is surplus to requirements and what is essential from a safety point of view. I see Senator Peter Baume nodding. It is very much like treating a patient. One cannot decide in one's approach to a patient that such and such a condition is life-threatening and that therefore treatment is essential but that treatment for a condition that is not life-threatening does not have to be carried out. One strives, in treating patients, to give them the best quality care one can in every element of treatment. Precisely the same ethos must apply in the maintenance of aircraft. One cannot say that, as something is not essential for the safe operation of the aircraft, it can be neglected. One must try to meet the highest standards of maintenance all along the line. It is terrible for Qantas, which has the proudest and finest safety record in the world, to be put in the position by the ideologies of the Labor Government of not being able to recruit adequate engineers.

One of the other problems Qantas is facing relates to pilots. The pilot shortage is compounded by Government practice. Australia pays its pilots, whether they fly for Qantas, Ansett Airlines of Australia or Australian Airlines, very well by world standards. If one looks at the last eight to 10 years of the international airline pilot scene one will find that most international operators have either pegged airline salaries, which were at a high level, or even reduced them. Some of the American operators have taken cuts of up to 20 to 30 per cent in their salaries. Concomitant with that has been an increase in the number of hours on duty that pilots are allowed to fly. In other words, the productivity of the flight deck crew has gone up considerably.

In Australia we suffer from overregulation in the whole of the aviation field. The number of hours that a pilot can actually fly is quite low, but they are made artificially much lower again because of overregulation which inhibits airlines from taking 100 per cent of the restricted hours a pilot is allowed to fly. The Government ought to be looking, through its new Civil Aviation Authority, at how to overcome some of these longstanding limitations on aircrew operations which are well in need of review.

Qantas has come in for criticism because it has poached very heavily from the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). The RAAF has a long-term loss rate of about 42 pilots per year. I do not wish to go into the resignation rates for all three Services. However, so that people have some idea of the magnitude of loss involved, the RAAF lost 70 pilots in 1985-86; 107 in 1986-87; 123 in 1987-88; and in the first six weeks of this financial year 42 pilots indicated that they were going. That is a loss of nearly 300 pilots from the RAAF. The active flying pool is not much larger than that. These are all pilots who have been trained by the taxpayer at vast expense. Most of them came from the operational squadrons, the F111s and the F18s, with about 10 to 12 years' service in the Air Force and about 1,000 hours on type. They have cost the taxpayers of this country between $4m and $6m each to train. Because they do not like the way this Government treats them, they are leaving to take what is a much more boring job for them of flying for Qantas.

It is a national tragedy that this should be happening. We do not need to pay $4m to $6m to train a Boeing 747 captain. We need to train Boeing 747 and 767 captains as well as we can, but we can do it for a fraction of what it costs to train the captain of an F111. One of the problems we have which pushes Qantas into poaching from the Services is that we spend nothing on aviation education in this country. We endow educational institutions with funds for basketweaving courses and all sorts of other non-essential courses. Colleges of advanced education, technical and further education colleges and universities have all sorts of hobby courses granting degrees. We pour hundreds of millions of dollars into them but we do not put one cent into training pilots or flight engineers. The training of a pilot is the most expensive training in the country.

To return to the Bill, the Government has guaranteed a loan of $US235m to Qantas. When I get into the details of the loan, I find the most astonishingly convoluted set of borrowing procedures I have ever seen in my life. I will simplify it. It starts with Qantas buying the aircraft from Boeing. It flies them to Sydney and they are sold to a company called Babcock and Brown. They then go to Japan and are bought by an affiliate company, Nomura, Babcock and Brown, and separate lease companies are set up for the aircraft. Then the company sells the lease to companies in the Cayman Islands and the Dutch Antilles. Qantas then eventually leases them back. We are assured by this honourable Government that it is all legal, but I have no hesitation in saying that if you or I did it, Mr Acting Deputy President, we could be up before the rapacious and law-breaking Mr Boucher for evading the tax law-Mr Boucher, who interprets what he thinks as the meaning of the income tax law, not worrying about the letter of the law.

I cannot help observing the double standards and the dubious morality of the Government in forcing Qantas to go down this path of shuffling through a chain of paper in companies all around the world-in Sydney, Tokyo, the Cayman Islands, the Dutch Antilles and then again Sydney. It is not proper for a government authority to be using these standards in its commercial operations. But I will yield to Senator Watson, who will go into this in more detail. I move:
At end of motion, add `, but the Senate:

(a) regrets that Qantas has been prevented from selling shares to Qantas employees and the Australian people to provide a capital increase to facilitate expansion of the airline to cope with increasing passengers and freight; and
(b) notes that the Australian Taxation Office has issued a statement on debt defeasance, a procedure adopted by Qantas to finance the acquisition of new aircraft'.

Qantas has a marvellous future. From the time it started on 2 November 1922 in western Queensland flying with an Armstrong Whitworth FK8 it has prospered year after year. It has proved that Australia can run a highly successful international airline. Originally Qantas was a private airline. It raised its own capital from shareholders. Right up to the end of the Second World War, in its difficult gestation period all its capital was raised by private industry. Then it was taken over by the Labor Government of the time and has remained a government entity ever since. Qantas provides great services to Australia. It is responsible for bringing 43 per cent of all the people who travel to Australia at present. It generates billions of dollars in overseas earnings for this country. The opportunities for Qantas in the Pacific region in the decades ahead are enormous. It is true that there are some risks in getting involved in this area, but the rewards more than compensate for them. It is very much in the national interest that Qantas be supported in fighting for and expanding its place in the markets in the Pacific and in the rest of the world.

I do not believe in the present trend towards mega-airlines such as the United complex and British Airways. Airlines are taking three or four, or even more, major airlines and consolidating them into one airline. There is a feeling about the international airline world that this is the only way airlines can survive. I do not believe that. In the longer haul, the mega-airlines will break up into more efficient economic units. I believe very strongly that there is a place for high quality airlines such as Qantas in the future. Its defence against the mega-airlines ought to be the formation of alliances with other high quality airlines rather than merging into one commercial behemoth.

The Government has completely run down the whole of the aviation scene in this country. We have had six Ministers, none of them competent, none of them adequate, in the five years this Government has been in office. We have seen the disbanding of the Department of Civil Aviation, after a variety of names, and the formation of the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority, neither of which is answerable to the Parliament for its incompetence. The airport scene, the chaos in Sydney and the shortage of an international terminal in Brisbane all point to the inadequacy this Government has brought so strikingly to the airline scene. We will support this Bill but we regret very much that the correct commercial procedure of selling the airline and raising capital through private industry was not followed in this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill 1988 and we will not be supporting the Opposition's amendment. For one thing, no advance notice of that amendment was given. In the previous debate on the Social Security (Review of Decisions) Bill 1988 Senator Messner was very scathing of my colleague Senator Powell when he said that she had not presented any amendment. In fact, the Opposition had known about the issues for a long time. In this instance, of course, the Opposition has not given us any advance notice. In any event we would not support the amendment because it calls for privatisation of Qantas Airways Ltd.
—As old socialists, you would not like it, would you?

—Senator MacGibbon interjects that I am perhaps a socialist. I am a humanist. I also believe in commonsense. Commonsense dictates that there is no guarantee that big business is any more efficient than big government. Big business is still subject to bureaucratic controls, Parkinson's law and the Peter principle. There is no guarantee that a privatised Qantas would be any more or any less efficient than a public Qantas. Incidentally, while I am on the subject of big business, Senator MacGibbon was quite scathing again of the route taken to purchase these aircraft, which is a devious route admittedly. It goes from Seattle to Sydney to Japan and to the Netherlands Antilles. This is what big business does. This is what Alan Bond does; this is what Kerry Packer does; this is big business. On the one hand, Senator MacGibbon wants this airline to be privatised but on the other he complains when the Government takes actions which are the actions that big business would be taking anyway. We do not support the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Qantas is an excellent airline. It is more than an airline; it is a national flag carrier; it is a symbol of Australia around the world. I come from the United States of America, which is very dedicated to big business. When I first came here I thought it strange that a country could actually run an airline or a railway or anything else. It smacked of communism or socialism because after all I am a product of the McCarthy era of United States thinking. However, I have changed my views. I believe that it is absolutely essential that Qantas remain in government hands. It does a good job as a flag carrier and an instrument of Australian goodwill around the world. People can see an extension of Australia, not in a warship-like way as we have seen in the harbours of Australia but in a peaceful way which is a means of actually building bridges of friendship across the world.

Senator MacGibbon was complaining about the standards of Qantas having slipped. I travel a fair bit and I travel on Qantas when I can. I have travelled on other airlines such as British Airways and United Airlines. Qantas compares very favourably with all the world's other airlines. It is a good airline. In fact, it is always good to get on a Qantas airliner after travelling on other airlines because one feels as though one is coming home.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—There are interjections from honourable senators to that effect. It is a good airline which is operated in a safe manner. Senator MacGibbon referred to the fact that Qantas airliners are taking off with some equipment unserviceable. This is true. I agree with Senator MacGibbon that it is deplorable that some of our mechanics are finding it necessary to leave Qantas in search of higher paying jobs elsewhere. But he makes it sound worse than it is. There is no machine of the complexity of a Boeing 747 that could be 100 per cent serviceable. One cannot expect all of its systems to be 100 per cent serviceable; it is a complicated machine. Because it is complicated a number of redundant systems, a number of back-up systems, can be unserviceable and the safety of the machine is not really affected. So while it is a deplorable situation, it is not one we should be unduly worried about. It is something we should keep our eyes on. We should spend more of our national resources on training aircraft pilots and people in the entire aircraft industry-aircraft controllers and aircraft mechanics.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing that does concern me, however, is a matter that was brought to my attention by the Australian International Cabin Crew Association, which is one of the unions which cover cabin crews on Qantas airliners. The second reading speech of the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill 1988 states that the Bill is to:

. . . finance the purchase of three Boeing 767-300 extended range aircraft. The aircraft will be delivered in October, November and December of this year . . . The aircraft will be utilised primarily on the Tasman and Japanese routes, two of Qantas, Australia's important markets.

They certainly are important, especially the Japanese route. Qantas has placed a series of advertisements in newspapers in Japan, Singapore, Thailand, Korea and Taiwan. An advertisement in the Singapore Straits Times on 19 March 1988 says:
Live in Sydney
See the World As
Qantas
Cabin Crew (Japanese-Speaking) . . .

You will find cabin crew life appealing if you are by nature caring and helpful, sensitive to the needs of others regardless of their cultural origins; patient and good humoured as well as steady and in control during emergencies. You must like working with others yet have the ability to cope with solitude; having worked in the service industry before, like in a hotel or restaurant or as a nurse or teacher will help.

So far so good. It says that any successful applicant will have assistance with housing on arrival in Sydney and will be given permanent residency. So far it sounds like a logical recruiting system but what does it really mean? There is a basic requirement that applicants must speak Japanese sufficiently for social occasions, speak English, plus speak their mother tongue fluently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who guarantees permanent residency? Qantas does, does it?

—The Government. Qantas has rightly determined that if one is going to run an airline which carries a number of Japanese people it would be good to have cabin attendants who speak Japanese. That is fine, but what it is doing is going outside the country to recruit Japanese speaking people. Qantas is planning to recruit between 16 and 18 persons from overseas to meet this new service standard. The company claims that it cannot meet its objectives for the next three to five years simply by training existing flight attendants even though Qantas received 700 applications from flight attendants wishing to enrol in Japanese language training programs advertised by the company earlier this year. So 700 existing attendants said, `Yes, we would like to learn Japanese' and Qantas said, `Forget it, we're going to start hiring people overseas'. It does not make sense to hire people from overseas to take positions which could be handled by people who are presently working for Qantas.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, this has caused quite a bit of consternation amongst the Australian International Cabin Crew Association and the Australian Council of Trade Unions-and rightly so. Qantas's argument that it must implement this procedure immediately-that is, hire Japanese speaking people from overseas-is not really logical, because during the last five years the number of Japanese tourists coming to Australia has quadrupled, increasing from 71,800 in 1983 to 286,000 in 1988, in spite of the fact that Qantas cabin attendants have not been speaking Japanese at the level which Qantas desires. So it looks like we do have a little time up our sleeves. We do need to address the needs of people from other countries who do not speak our language, but actually to hire people overseas is, I think, wrong. I am particularly disturbed that these people are being brought in as permanent residents and not as temporary residents, because the permanency that is being offered to them leads me to question Qantas's commitment to training adequate numbers of Australian crew. This is a difficulty that we have with Qantas at the moment. I think it is a difficulty which can be solved. It is a relatively minor difficulty compared to the one I will mention next-the difficulties for Qantas in operating in Australia.

When Qantas flights return home and are put in holding patterns outside Sydney before they can land, it is not only inconvenient for the passengers but also very expensive for Qantas, as this must burn up an awful lot of fuel. As an environmentalist, I am very concerned about the vast amount of fuel which is burnt by Qantas flights being placed in holding patterns before they can land in Sydney. This difficulty is common to any other aircraft using Sydney airport. As Senator MacGibbon said, it is a result of the incapacity of the Australian Government-of both stripes, Labor and Liberal-to come to grips with modern air traffic control procedures. Air traffic control in Sydney simply does not work. If the busy airports of the world, such as Los Angeles International, O'Hare in Chicago, Heathrow, or those in Rome or Athens used the traffic control procedures used in Sydney, traffic would simply stop. Our traffic control procedures simply are not working.

Another difficulty relating to Sydney airport is the lack of runways. There is a relatively low cost solution. As much, or some, of the traffic which uses Sydney is made up of light twins and commuter-type airlines, it would be logical to put in a runway for their sole use, as occurred at Los Angeles International. I think the authorities are costing another runway for Sydney in terms of jet operations-747 and 767 aircraft operations; the heavy aircraft. It would be far cheaper and quicker to put in a 3,000 or 4,000 feet strip for the commuter airlines and the light twin aircraft. This would ease traffic congestion. It is not the ultimate solution, which involves a more modern, efficient and flexible air traffic control system in Sydney and Melbourne. Melbourne also has difficulties at the moment. Qantas flights are also put in holding patterns there. Melbourne has adequate runways but a very inadequate air traffic control system due to the radar system which has been installed.

I will not delay the Senate any longer. Qantas deserves our support. I hope that it gets the support that it needs, and I hope that aviation in Australia in general gets the support that it needs. Aviation in Australia is essential to Australia's development. Aviation had its start in Australia. Australia led the world in the use of aviation. Much of Australia was settled and explored by the use of aircraft. In the years that have followed since Kingsford-Smith and the early pioneers, Australia has gone backwards until we are now one of the poor relations of aviation in the world. We do not give it enough resources; we do not give it enough attention. I think it is time that Australia came to the forefront in aviation matters and took the lead in using aviation for what it can best do-that is, adequately develop Australia's future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill 1988. Before we conclude this debate, I believe that the Senate is entitled to receive certain assurances from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) that Qantas does not propose to enter into funding arrangements which could be in conflict with the war by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on tax avoidance and the Federal Government's taxation objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has been advocating a tax policy over a period of many months which has emphasised its commitment to deal with taxpayers who minimise their obligations and thereby involve themselves in tax avoidance practices. The Commissioner of Taxation has supported this deal with a number of contentious taxation rulings and by engaging in raids on premises of banks, solicitors and chartered accountants. Although there has never been any violence involved in these raids on premises, I have been told by some of the participants that they have been psychologically brutal.

Of course, we, as committed and responsible citizens, must accept that we have a duty to pay our tax and not seek to evade it. I think, however, that it is important in this debate and similar debates to remind the Senate that every taxpayer has a right or entitlement, which is always upheld in the courts, to minimise one's tax liability within the law. The Senate needs to be assured that, in regard to the Bill before the Senate, the present Treasurer does not have schizophrenic tendencies. For example, I am sure that the Senate would be concerned if a situation developed whereby the Treasurer had a penchant for minimising tax avoidance obligations and, at the same time, a willingness through his Government to put forward a Bill which had behind it all the hallmarks of funding to purchase three new aircraft, with constraints on the deal to ensure that that deal was in line with taxation policy and philosophy.

One would hope in all cases that a statutory body-which would obviously include Qantas-would operate within the policy guidelines of the Government's taxation policy and philosophy. I think it is arguable that Qantas in the past has always operated within the law, but under the proposed funding arrangements it could well contravene the guidelines enunciated by the Treasurer and the Taxation Commissioner, particularly if it adopts funding proposals which are similar to those which have been adopted in the past. For example, a quite reliable newspaper report in the Sydney Morning Herald recently indicated that Qantas had sought defeasance on its purchase of aircraft in the past by pursuing a complex set of deals involving the purchase and repurchase of a number of its aircraft. I ask the Minister: Has Qantas contracted deals for the purchase of these aircraft which are the subject of this loan guarantee Bill? In such a contract members of the web could include not only Qantas and Boeing but also outsiders such as a Japanese leasing company or some other leasing company, dozens of Japanese or other investors, and certain banks, possibly even the Barclays Bank. Such a deal could traverse countries such as Australia, Japan, and a number of tax haven island nation states, possibly in the Caribbean. We have to beware of a government instrumentality being involved in a deal that is contrived between such groups in order to take advantage of the taxation systems in Australia and Japan and tax haven areas resulting, naturally, in Qantas saving some after-tax money or reducing the cost of the aircraft purchase.

I ask the Minister to deny that there has been a deal such as that which I will illustrate by way of an example, or a similar deal. I hope the Minister will not hide behind some technical inaccuracy, by saying that certain names or countries are incorrect. I will give an example of the sort of arrangement that I feel could be quite abhorrent, given the Taxation Commissioner's high and new moral ground in relation to this area. Qantas orders aircraft from Boeing. It then sells the aircraft to Japan with an intermediate bank paying Qantas. Naturally, under Japanese law, the Japanese owners would qualify for tax benefits and depreciation allowances. Then the Japanese issue Qantas with a lease and an option to buy the planes on hire purchase. Qantas then buys the planes back through an intermediate bank. Qantas pays the bank a fee to defease rental obligations and part of the purchase option. The planes are bought back on hire purchase, or through a similar deal, and become Australian again and qualify Qantas for tax benefits and depreciation under tax rules here. At the end of all this Qantas would be able to achieve what is known within the trade as `debt defeasance' and it would get an after-tax benefit. So Qantas would acquire the planes ultimately at a much cheaper cost than if it had bought them directly from the manufacturers.

That is a scant look at what, of course, is a very complicated deal. There is nothing illegal about the deal in itself. It has been mentioned elsewhere in this debate that if the airline were to be privatised, naturally these sorts of purchasing arrangements would be not only common but also necessary to maximise profits. It concerns me that in the light of the Taxation Commissioner's commitment to the minimisation of individual tax avoidance arrangements, the activities of Qantas in its purchase of aircraft may be bringing the Tax Commissioner and a government owned instrumentality into conflict, certainly moral conflict.

On the issue of privatisation I wish to point out that the coalition is committed to the privatisation of a number of government organisations, including Qantas. It is believed nowadays that the Commonwealth does not have a role, indeed it cannot afford the luxury, in owning airlines and certain other statutory bodies, and that money that is tied up in these sorts of instrumentalities would be better spent on providing government services to more pressing sectors and areas. I am not implying in any way that the current management of Qantas, for whom I have a high regard, is lacking. But Qantas must often be frustrated at the fact that the airline is being kept in cotton wool by being a wholly government-owned entity and not subject to all the benefits and pressures of the private sector.

The conflict that has developed between Government policy and the activities of one of its bodies highlights another cause for the case for privatisation. Government enterprises such as Qantas are expected to operate with the same management philosophy and techniques as the private organisations in such a highly competitive environment. The airline industry is a highly competitive one and in order for a government-owned airline to operate profitably, the organisation needs to be free to compete and to deal in the same manner as do its competitors. Consequently, it is not in Australia's best interest that the Australian national airline be constrained by government policy and run the risk of compromising this policy through competitive activities.

The conflict of policy which I have just described to the Senate is not the sole argument that can be made for privatisation. The coalition certainly believes, and very strongly so, that privatisation can contribute to the improvement of public operations. For example, Qantas is burdened by Public Service conditions, as is Australian Airlines, that make Qantas and Australian Airlines less competitive than their private sector rivals. Qantas, which we acknowledge is an efficient international airline in its own right, is hampered by its inability to fill seats while flying from one Australian airport to another. It is also limited in its ability to do international deals, to invest in tourist activities generally, and to compete as quite an ambitious international airline.

The Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill is but another example of the constraints that are placed upon our national airline. As my colleague Senator MacGibbon said, Qantas does have inadequate capitalisation, an inadequate capital base. While private enterprise airlines can raise most of the money for these very expensive new aircraft by selling various forms of shares, the undercapitalised government airline, which Qantas is, is forced to borrow and pay huge interest bills. In fact, Qantas's total capital base is provided by the Government at present and is insufficient to buy even two-thirds of one Boeing 747-400 at today's prices. In order for Qantas to remain profitable in the future an increased capital base is required to permit a reduction in the extensive borrowing necessary to effect the forthcoming purchase re-equipment program.

It must also be noted that although Qantas is helped in raising borrowings at competitive rates by having a government guarantee on its loans, the Federal Government has, since 1987, imposed a 0.5 per cent levy on all loans that it guarantees for its instrumentalities, including Qantas. Thus, the Government has found another source from which it can syphon off funds. In 1987, Qantas ordered four new high technology 747-400s costing about $250m each. But several of its competitors ordered more 747-400s for earlier delivery. The problem is that although Qantas had the option on a further dozen, it could not afford to borrow more to pay for them. So the opportunity to introduce the new aircraft earlier than its rivals could well have provided Qantas with a competitive edge, an increased market share and increased profitability. In fact, a privately owned Qantas would be expected to have the capital base and the borrowing capacity to secure the deal that I have just referred to. Privatisation would free the airline from government restrictions on its borrowings and other financial operations.

I think it is appropriate in 1988, our bicentennial year, to reflect on the tremendous number of tourists that have been flocking to Australia from all around the world. This year we have had probably more visits by heads of state and heads of government than in any other year since Federation. We have seen historically memorable events, such as the Australia Day celebrations in Sydney Harbour, the opening of World Expo 88 in Brisbane and the opening of our grand new Parliament House here in Canberra. Many of these visitors would have come to Australia on Qantas aeroplanes and I was pleased to note that recently Qantas received a very high rating from regular air travellers in all countries of the world. As Qantas is the oldest airline in the English speaking world and I think the oldest airline overall apart from KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, I believe we can be justly proud of the achievements of our own airline.

Therefore I hope that the Federal Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, Mr Gary Punch, will put pressure on the Government to permit Qantas to carry more domestic passengers. I know that this area has been freed up recently and the Government is to be commended for its forward thinking change. But I see that more than half of the 14 million people who have attended Expo were Australians and I think it would have assisted the domestic network and domestic operators if Qantas had been able to carry some of those passengers. At present the domestic operators, particularly Ansett, have an acute shortage of planes. This factor frequently interrupts regular airline schedules to Tasmania.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that recently Her Royal Highness the Duchess of York was displeased when she attempted to undertake a scheduled flight to Tasmania by Ansett, which flight was changed at the last minute because of the shortage of aircraft and resulted in her chartering a special plane. Unfortunately for travellers to my State, the domestic carriers have been rescheduling aircraft away from Tasmania in favour of the more populous States. The point I am making is that the change I have suggested would provide a goldmine of extra revenue to Qantas if certain Qantas services could carry interstate passengers at no prejudice to its other international schedules.

It is my hope and it is coalition policy that when the Howard government is elected at the next election immediate steps will be taken to free Qantas from its last links with the Commonwealth Government. The Howard government would naturally do the same for Australian Airlines, as Ansett and the other airlines show that private enterprise can very efficiently run an Australian airline. In conclusion, the Opposition supports the Bill. We are putting forward a number of amendments which I trust will be carried. We hope that soon Qantas will be another element in the spectrum of proud private sector successes contributing to the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is indebted to the Opposition for its support of the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill, but we are not especially indebted for the series of misconceived criticisms of aspects of the current behaviour of Qantas Airways Ltd and the Government's approach to Qantas's financial problems which have governed the course of the debate so far. Certainly the Government will not support-it will come as no news to the Opposition-the amendment that has been proposed to the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the debate, inevitably, has focused on the particular question of Qantas's capital structure and the need, arguably, for some form of capital injection to ensure that the investments which we all know and appreciate the airline needs to carry out in the years ahead will be affordable without teasing out too far the debt to equity ratio of the company and giving an insufficient capital base on which that expansion can occur. We are all familiar with the problem. It has been amply debated in the public arena over a long time and is still being very actively considered within the Government.

I do not in any way concede that the state of Qantas's capital structure at the moment has been an inhibition to the expansion program and the aircraft acquisition program which have been embarked upon to date. Nor do I believe it will constitute an inhibition in the future. There are a number of ways in which one can address this issue, including going back and testing some of the assumptions about appropriate debt to equity ratios and so on for a government owned company of this kind. All of those matters are subject to active consideration, as I say, by the Government and by the governing party and I am sure that over the course of the next few months a satisfactory solution will emerge. Certainly in the past this Government has not been in the slightest bit unwilling to respond to capital needs as they arise.

Since Qantas was purchased by the Chifley Australian Labor Party Government from the British Government and Australian private interests back in 1947, the company has received a total of $148.4m in capital injection. Of that, Qantas received $66.2m in just 10 years of Labor governments and $82.2m from Liberal and National party governments-admittedly a larger sum of money, but spread over 31 years of Qantas's activity.

I think it needs to be appreciated that as the occasions have arisen government has moved-in particular, Labor governments have moved-quickly to respond to those needs. We certainly did so in 1983 when we injected $60m, raising paid-up capital from $89m to $149m, an increase of 67 per cent. In addition, of course, it needs to be acknowledged that the Government did move to improve the commercial operation of the company, with new guidelines being issued to Qantas directors, giving them responsibilities for the operation of the company and in particular removing the kind of day-to-day control and oversight that has traditionally been associated with the Government's supervision of Qantas which I think has been a serious inhibiter to it developing a fully commercial ethos. All of those things this Government has been responsive to and has done a great deal to dispel the notion that the Government will somehow let Qantas either hit the fence or be incapable of expansion in terms of the fleet and of acquisition, where relevant and necessary, of interests in other companies. I do not think the record in any way bears out that notion.

The Government's intention is certainly to ensure that this company continues to ride the waves of the massive continuing expansion of the international aviation scene that we all want it to be able to ride in order to take full advantage for the nation of the income flows in external currencies that are associated with that expanding capacity. So the the capital injection issue and the whole argument that is encapsulated in the first clause of the Opposition's amendment is I think a furphy and will prove to be such quite clearly over the next few months as the issue is addressed by the Government in the way that we intend to do.

The other major theme of the debate, as I understand it, has been the argument that the particular financing arrangement that has been adopted by Qantas to secure the acquisition of new aircraft is somehow at risk or colourable under Australian Taxation Office (ATO) rulings that have been made at particular times, in particular the ruling about defeasance of debt. What needs to be appreciated-and this point along with all the others has been made by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, in the other place, but unfortunately it seems to need repetition on these occasions-is that the leases in question have been undertaken on three previous occasions: November 1986, May 1987 and August 1987. Each one of those three previous proposals has been cleared by the ATO. Although the ATO was not approached on this occasion, the reason was that this proposal is basically the same as was previously the case. The Qantas arrangements are very different from those recently moved against by the ATO.

In the case that was the subject of the ruling and that has got the Opposition so excited, principal only was defeased, whereas in the Qantas case both principal and interest are defeased and the effect of that is tax neutral. That does not seem to have penetrated the Opposition's mind, even though it was stated explicitly to be the case in the House of Representatives debate. The most clear cut assessment of the ruling in question will make that clear. One does not go on putting things back to the ATO when one has had clearance on three previous occasions, when the particular arrangement proposed is not different to any significant extent from those earlier clearances, and when the tax ruling, which may at first sight appear to be on the same subject and to militate against it, on closer examination proves to do nothing of the kind because it is addressed to an arrangement which is different in kind to that in issue here. I think that does constitute a complete answer to the concerns of the Opposition on this point.

I also make the point that the kinds of arrangements in question are common practice in the airline industry. American Airlines has undertaken a number of them. CAAC, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd are also known to have used them. The notion that was advanced by Senator MacGibbon-that somehow the Government should not be in the airlines business, not least because private companies can embark upon or enter into money raising arrangements more cheaply than can a government airline-really rather comprehensively misses the point when he criticises the government airline, Qantas, for embarking upon a money raising exercise in exactly the same way the private sector has been doing, and in a way which does not involve, as I repeat, any undermining of the Tax Office rulings which are applicable in these particular circumstances.

That is, I think, as much as needs to be said on that topic. If honourable senators want to check it out in any more detail, I am sure the Minister for Transport and Communications will be only too happy to give them the full chapter and verse on that. I repeat: taxation ruling 2495 is aimed at structures where only principal is defeased and that is completely different from the present situation where both principal and interest are subject to those defeasance arrangements.

That leaves only a couple of other matters that have been the subject of attention, I understand, during the second reading debate. Senator MacGibbon raised the question of the shortage of skilled tradesmen, or tradespeople as we are now obliged to call them. The situation is this: Qantas and the domestic airlines are suffering from a shortage of skilled and semi-skilled tradespeople-that is well acknowledged. However, there has been a concerted effort to alleviate the situation. Qantas is increasing its intake of apprentices; it is recruiting staff overseas; and it aims to restructure awards to facilitate greater flexibility and scope for more competitive conditions. Again we have had some maintenance work being subcontracted to overseas firms so as to decrease the backlog and the pressure on Qantas maintenance staff. We are aiming to expand our maintenance facilities to provide maintenance for overseas airlines in the future, which will earn the company valuable foreign exchange. Obviously, in order to do that we need to have an ample supply of skilled tradesmen.

What should also be added to that description of the activities of Qantas in this respect is an appreciation that the current shortage stems from action that was taken by Qantas in 1982 and 1983 to stop recruiting apprentices in the light of the airline recession which was current at that stage. Other airlines, both Australian and Ansett, did the same. All of them now acknowledge that that was a very short-sighted response to what proved to be a very transient situation. The airline industry picked up in a major way shortly thereafter. The basic point is that the Government's centralised wage-fixing system cannot be blamed in any way for the shortage. It is directly and squarely attributable to, in effect, a cessation in the supply of apprentices during those crucial years of 1982 and 1983, and any careful examination of the record will amply show that to be the case.

The final matter that I think deserves a brief reference is one raised by Senator Sanders involving a criticism of the plans of Qantas to recruit Japanese speakers in Asia for its Japan-oriented flights in particular. The response to that is as follows: fears that Qantas is denying jobs to Australians are quite unfounded. Qantas already employs 3,300 flight attendants and it plans to recruit nearly 500 flight attendants each year over the next few years to meet its rapid expansion program. As part of its $6m program to strengthen Asian language skills among Australians, Qantas has already provided employment and training opportunities for more than 500 Australians. Qantas has recruited more than 100 Australians who speak an Asian language, has provided language training for 200 staff and has provided scholarships, cadetships or other assistance to Australians outside Qantas.

However, even with all of that enormous level of activity, Qantas still needs more Japanese speaking flight attendants than have been able to be supplied through that kind of recruitment activity. Of the 520 who were recruited this year only 30 speak Japanese, and only 45 existing flight attendants have to date undergone intensive Japanese language training. What has happened is that Qantas has taken on 28 Japanese speaking attendants from Asia to meet its short term requirements, and it is seeking permanent residency for them in line with its general policy to recruit either Australian citizens or permanent residents.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are making them permanent residents?

—We are making them permanent residents, sure, which means it is not just a transient phenomenon for those people. But what we are seeking to do is to meet the problem in other ways. It is just that in the short term it cannot be met other than by direct recruitment.
—Permanent residence is hardly a short term gap filling exercise.
—It is a short term gap filling exercise, but those particular people are being recruited on the basis that they will have permanent residence if they, in fact, seek and want it.
—This sounds like something out of Alice in Wonderland.

—I do not think the honourable senator was quite listening. The number of staff who are going to be needed grows and grows each year. It is hoped that in future years the new staff coming on to add to the existing pool will be able to be overwhelmingly supplied from domestic sources or through further retraining of existing Australian flight staff. Until that can happen the pool has to be added to by overseas recruitment on a very small scale in the way that I have described. I am sure Senator Sanders will be fair-minded enough to appreciate that that is a pretty good response to the particular concern that he raised.

SPEECH.PARA: There were some other lesser matters inevitably raised in the course of a debate as wide-ranging as this, but I think that does address the main concerns that have arisen during the debate. I repeat: I am indebted to the Senate for its support of the measure itself, and I wish it a speedy passage.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator MacGibbon's) be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has acknowledged that the purchase involves certain defeasance arrangements. He added a rider that these arrangements are not quite identical to some previous arrangements. But is the Government not concerned that one arm of government is in conflict with another office of government in that the standards which are demanded by one section conflict with the operations of another? Secondly, why was it thought prudent not to get Australian Taxation Office approval in this last transaction when it saw fit on three previous occasions to get such advice and approval from the Taxation Office? Was not the Government aware that the Taxation Commissioner has issued a recent ruling which substantially changed the previous arrangements, including the present funding arrangements under which Qantas Airways Ltd operates? If there were no alleged taxation benefits for the acquisition of expensive aircraft or, as is alleged, the position is taxation neutral, may we have an assurance to that effect? What are the taxation benefits in Australia for Qantas entering such a complicated arrangement if there are not these sorts of tax benefits? What were the benefits of entering these costly and complicated arrangements involving transactions encompassing at least three or more overseas countries?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of these questions have been answered already in the course of my second reading reply. What is in it for Qantas Airways Ltd to enter into that sort of arrangement is not a tax advantage as such but cheaper finance from the Japanese investment houses which, by virtue of this arrangement, are able to benefit from some provisions in, I presume, Japanese law. But whatever those provisions are they have a benefit in entering into a leasing arrangement of this kind. It is not a benefit of a kind which is thought to raise public interest or public policy so far as the Japanese Government is concerned, and certainly not so far as the Australian Government is concerned-that is as to the motivation for entering it-but the particular arrangement has been cleared on three previous occasions by the Australian Taxation Office. Apart from one variation-that is to say, a shorter lease term from 15 to 12 years-the features of these leases are exactly the same as those previously approved. Subsequently an arrangement has been ruled against in Taxation ruling IT-2495, but that is aimed at structures where only the principal is defeased whereas under this arrangement that Qantas has entered into both principal and interest are involved. This makes it, financially speaking and in terms of tax law, a completely different proposition and one that is quite tax neutral in the Australian context. Beyond giving that answer again, with knobs on and three times over, I cannot do better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to dinner I was questioning the Minister about the debt defeasance arrangements of Qantas Airways Ltd-a financing arrangement for the purchase of these three new Boeing 767 aircraft. These arrangements lie behind this Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill. One of the matters of principal concern is the possibility of conflict between the interpretations of two arms of government-that is, of Qantas Airways Ltd and the Australian Taxation Office, supported by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who takes a high moral ground on tax avoidance. I was speaking about the propriety of these arrangements by virtue of a recent ruling by the Australian Taxation Office on tax defeasance arrangements. I ask the Minister the question again and emphasise the seriousness of it: why was the Australian Taxation Office not consulted on this arrangement on this occasion, whereas on previous occasions it was consulted separately? Will the Minister confirm that there were no taxation benefits-and I ask the Minister to listen very carefully to this-including tax timing advantages which resulted from these transactions? Finally, if there were alleged tax benefits in the previous arrangements involving maximising taxation advantage in both Japan and Australia, how does the Minister now come to the conclusion that under these new arrangements, which are almost identical, except for a shorter time span, the only benefits to Qantas were lower interest charges on its debt and not taxation benefits now or in the future?

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Minister has only taken advice from the officials of Qantas who were not prepared to go before the Australian Taxation Office, despite a change in the ruling of recent times, will he now adjourn this debate until he takes advice from the Taxation Office, lest he leave himself open to the serious charge of misleading the Senate on this question? If there is nothing unusual in this at least three-country, multipurpose financing transaction, will the Minister table the Qantas defeasance arrangements in the Senate for public scrutiny?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Clear advice available to Qantas Airways Ltd was that the structure of the financing arrangement was so different from the particular arrangement that was the subject of the Australian Taxation Office ruling that there was simply no question likely to arise in any reasonable person's mind as to any potential change in the ground rules of liability. That is my clear understanding. Qantas sought advice from its advising merchant banker-or certainly professional advice of some kind-and it acted in accordance with what it had understood to be clearly well established principles with the Tax Office. Should the Tax Office choose to get further information from Qantas in the light of issues that have been raised in this debate, which seems to me to be manifestly unlikely on the basis of all the information available to me, it is perfectly entitled to do that. I am sure Qantas would cooperate fully. We want Qantas to operate as a commercial company. That seems to be something to which the Opposition is as committed to bringing about as we are. When it enters into financial arrangements which reduce the financial liability which is associated with the financing in question and does so on the basis of a course of practice which would be completely acceptable in the private sector on the basis of advice which a private sector company would obtain, there would not seem to be legitimate grounds for grievance.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the question about changing the timing of tax liability, I have already answered the earlier question. There is no change in information available to me as to the tax neutrality of it in terms of actual tax liability. As to the timing of it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Including timing differences?

—I will just quote from the relevant paragraph of the letter from the advising accountant, Arthur Andersen and Co., which relates to an earlier transaction which, I presume, was identical in all respects:

SPEECH.PARA: We would note that the hire purchase arrangement does not in any way accelerate tax deductions for financing charges payable under the hire purchase agreement which Qantas would enter into with BIL. It would enable Qantas to avoid having to incur most of the additional costs at all. Thus, no tax deductions would be sought by Qantas for any financing charges which have been assumed by the bank and which would otherwise have been incurred by it under the hire purchase arrangement. The only interest charges which Qantas will incur will be the interest component of the final purchase option payment.

Again, there is nothing in the current arrangement which in any way is different in any relevant respect so far as that question of accelerating tax deductions is concerned. I do not think there is any other timing question that is involved in this. While I admire the indefatigable way in which this matter is being pursued by Senator Watson and the Opposition, there is nothing more than I can add. I will raise with Qantas whether there are any commercially confidential considerations which would stand in the way of the relevant material being tabled but I am obviously not in a position to make such a judgment on the run tonight on the basis of information and advice available to me now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I ask: Is the Minister prepared to adjourn this debate while he gets independent advice from the Australian Taxation Office? The letter that he quoted from related to a previous occasion when the law was different as now interpreted by the Australian Taxation Office by virtue of a recent ruling that has been handed down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in any doubt, and I am not prepared to adjourn this matter. What I am anxious to do is ensure that Qantas can get on with the business of leasing aircraft which are absolutely crucial to its commercial viability and to the rate of return which this nation can reasonably expect to get from its own international airline. If there is any lingering doubt in the minds of the Opposition senators or anyone else, the matter can be referred to the Australian Taxation Office and it can act accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: Qantas is obviously supremely confident of the technical validity of its position. That is the advice available to it. It seems, on the basis of the advice that is put in front of me, that the structure of the financing arrangement is completely different from the one that is the subject of the Tax Office ruling, and on the basis of that information and the advice available to me I make the point that we want this legislation to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier Senator MacGibbon described the process whereby the aeroplanes in question came from the United States to Australia, then went to Japan, following which the ownership was transferred to the Cayman Islands and then back to Australia. Senator Watson indicates that I have the process about right. Are we to understand that that is in any way a normal purchasing process by Qantas for the aeroplanes it flies? I thought Senator Watson was asking some questions in relation to that most unusual set of transactions. The Minister might just clarify that for us. I have been listening carefully, and it is not clear.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Circuitous as it may sound, this sort of thing is par for the course in the highly complex world of aircraft purchases and capital financing. I am told that the kind of arrangement in issue here is common practice in the airline industry. American Airlines has undertaken a number of arrangements of this kind. That may well be where Qantas derived its information which has enabled it to put together this deal, because of its close working relationship with American Airlines. I do not know about that. CAAC, KLM and Cathay Pacific are also known to have used this particular complex leasing financial arrangement. So it is my understanding that it is perfectly common airline commercial practice, and I repeat that the taxation implications of this kind of arrangement-not some different kind of arrangement but this one-were checked out with the Australian Taxation Office on three occasions and clearances were given. On that basis Qantas has proceeded to implement this essentially routine commercial arrangement.

—We acknowledge that transactions involving many people and many companies are commonplace within the airline industry, but my concern is that a government instrumentality could well be in conflict with the high moral ground taken by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and now by the Australian Taxation Office in relation to tax avoiding schemes. Does not this transaction result in an otherwise artificially higher purchase price to Qantas at the end of the day, giving it higher depreciation write-offs and other benefits?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only repeat the advice available to me: in tax terms, the arrangement is entirely neutral. It is the actual financing costs, the interest burden and the cash costs associated with paying for the aircraft that are cheaper for Qantas. Everything else has a taxation implication. I have not mastered the technical details; I can only operate on the basis of the advice put in front of me, and the clear advice from the accountants, and this has been accepted by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in the past, is that this is absolutely tax neutral. The advantages are of a different kind.

SPEECH.PARA: In no way will the passage of this legislation tonight inhibit the Tax Office from making any further inquiry that it may wish to make of Qantas. There is no question of the legislation foreclosing any further such scrutiny, and if there is any hint of a suggestion that there is something colourable about this, no doubt the ATO will want to scrutinise it further. That is as it should be with any commercial organisation. I can only operate on the advice and the information available to me, and I see absolutely nothing that is colourable in the transaction by reference to either the technical black letter of the law or the high moral principles which I am delighted to hear the Opposition espousing. It makes a considerable sea change from the way it normally approaches these issues, and in particular the extraordinary way it has approached the very aggressive approach to tax avoidance adopted by Tax Commissioner Boucher in recent times. I very much welcome this surge of enthusiasm for tax morality and effective tax enforcement practice. I hope we hear a lot more of it in this chamber; I just hope we do not hear too much more of it on this Bill because I have about 13 meetings to go to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been assured that it has been the standard practice under Labor for Qantas to buy its aircraft through all these front companies buying leases and shuffling them from one pocket to another, using dubious capital in some cases, with ownership transferring all around the world. Is this the practice for the internal airlines as well? Do Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines buy their aircraft this way and, further, can we look forward to the Royal Australian Air Force buying its aircraft under the same system?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have absolutely no idea of the practice in so far as the internal airlines are concerned. I am sure it is something that Senator MacGibbon can pursue on another occasion. I do not think it is relevant to the legislation before us.

I did not know that the Cayman Islands had an airstrip large enough to take a 747 aircraft. I must say I have come into this debate a little late, but am I to understand that somehow Qantas planes are shuttled through the Cayman Islands?

—Oh, the paper only; I also apologise to Senator Watson because when the division bells rang prior to dinner I was at a place in Parliament House which was almost exactly four minutes walk away.
