PROCTEXT.PARA: Referral to Committee
Debate resumed from 14 October, on motion by Senator Macklin:

(1) That, acknowledging that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has unanimously recommended that the Commonwealth should introduce comprehensive legislation to assume responsibility for all areas covered by the co-operative scheme and that a package of Bills for this purpose is now before the Senate, the Bills be referred to a select committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, and the Committee inquire into and report on the Bills for the regulation of companies and the securities and futures industries with reference only to the adequacy of the proposed legislative provisions to:
(a) improve the regulation of companies;
(b) facilitate the performance of the securities and futures markets; and
(c) ensure adequate protection for investors in companies and the securities and futures markets,
and, in particular, report on the adequacy of the fund-raising provisions.
(2) That the Committee consist of 10 members, as follows:
(a) 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate,
(b) 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate,
(c) 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats,
(d) 3 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by or on behalf of the Prime Minister, and
(e) 2 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition.
(3) That the Committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all the members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by or on behalf of the Prime Minister or by the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the Committee being equally divided, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That the quorum of the Committee be 5 members.

(8) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, and the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(9) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be all the members appointed to the sub-committee.

(10) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) That the Committee report to each House of the Parliament by the first day of sitting of that House in 1989.

(13) That the Committee have access to any relevant evidence and records of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.
(14) That the Committee cease upon the dissolution or expiration of the House of Representatives.
(15) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.
(16) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution be communicated by Message to the House of Representatives with a request for the concurrence of that House in the Resolution.
(17) That consideration of the motion for the second reading of the Bills be an Order of the Day for the day on which the Committee reports to the Senate-
Upon which Senator Hill had moved by way of amendment:
Leave out paragraph (1), insert:

``(1) That the Bills be referred to a select committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, and the Committee examine the Bills for unintended legal and commercial consequences, and report whether:
(a) the Bills and the scheme thereby created meet the legitimate needs of the business community, all State Governments and other interested groups within the community;

(b) passage of the Bills and the scheme thereby created is the only means of facilitating further national and international development of Australian business, or whether a modified cooperative scheme could achieve such objectives, and in particular whether a transfer to the Commonwealth of takeover and associated securities provisions could achieve the Government's stated objectives;
(c) an efficient regulatory system can be achieved by an alternative scheme other than that proposed by the Bills, i.e., the complete centralisation of power;
(d) the interests of shareholders and the broader investor community are adequately protected by the Bills;
(e) it is desirable and advisable to proceed with passage of the Bills considering the serious constitutional concerns which have been raised regarding their validity; and
(f) passage of the Bills will result in:
(i) the loss by the State regulatory authorities and their respective business communities of accessibility and the ability to influence policy and law-making;
(ii) additional costs to business;
(iii) a loss of skilled staff from State corporate affairs offices;
(iv) loss of business and professional expertise in the States as a result of the transfer of power from the States to the Federal Government; and
(v) adequate funding and resources to ensure that the regulatory system can function efficiently and react promptly to immediate concerns.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I last addressed the Australian Securities Commission Bill and associated Bills I was dealing with the proposition put to the chamber by the Australian Democrats-that is, to refer the Corporations Bill and the related Bills to a Senate committee, but with restricted terms of reference, first to improve the regulation of companies; second to facilitate the performance of the securities and futures markets; and third to ensure adequate protection for investors in companies and the securities and futures markets. The Democrats propose that we embrace the thrust of the legislation but ask that it be slightly finetuned in a few places. The amendment does not question the legislation or doubt it; it does not go to the heart of its merit or its virtue.

SPEECH.PARA: However, Senator Robert Hill has a subsequent amendment which goes to the heart of the problem which confronts the chamber. The amendment deals with all the essential problems inherent in legislation of this nature. He asks that the terms of reference of the Committee be widened to include whether an efficient regulatory system has been achieved by a scheme other than that proposed by the Bills, that is, the complete centralisation of power. That is a very reasonable question to ask. He asks whether the interests of shareholders in the broader investment community are adequately protected by the Bills. He asks whether it is desirable or advisable to proceed with the passage of the Bills, considering the serious constitutional concerns which have been raised regarding their validity. He asks whether the passage of the Bills will result in the loss by the State regulatory authorities and their respective business communities of accessibility and the ability to influence policy and law making. He also raises a number of other matters. As I say, the Democrats are not challenging the premise of the legislation but, by their motion, are acknowledging their support for it.

In the short time available to me I am unable to address all the matters that are raised in Senator Hill's amendment. He raises the fundamental threshold question of the constitutional validity of the proposals. I think it was Senator Hill himself who asked in the midst of his speech where we would be if, this legislation having been enacted, it were subsequently challenged in the High Court and found to be without constitutional power. I assume that the Government is relying on section 51 of the Constitution, which on first reading seems to be limited to foreign corporations and trading or financial corporations formed within the limits of the Commonwealth. I gather from the way that the Democrats have embraced this legislation that they are relying, as the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs did, upon the untarnished opinion offered by Sir Maurice Byers as to whether this power will enable the Commonwealth to enact comprehensive overriding Commonwealth legislation. Sir Maurice Byers indicated that in his opinion it would. It is not, I think, uncharitable or unkind to observe that in recent times Sir Maurice Byers has been wrong more often than he has been right.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is absolutely nothing uncharitable about it.

—The honourable senator is quite right. There was nothing uncharitable about that comment; it was simply a statement of fact. Senator Hill referred to those authorities which counselled against his judgment. I think it was a committee of the various State Solicitors-General that took a quite contrary view. It seems not unreasonable that that question be determined before we proceed with the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will touch on some of the other matters that have been raised. Perhaps one ought to ask what it is that brings this legislation before us. Has the present cooperative scheme failed? Has there been a clamouring amongst the States for this legislation? Has there been a spontaneous and natural call from small, medium and large businesses for this legislation? Is the existing legislation in some sort of crisis? Why are we junking a cooperative federalist system which has worked effectively and which, whilst perhaps having defects of the type that are inevitable with cooperative federalism, has the support and goodwill of all the States? We are jettisoning that system for something else which seems to have no support other than that of the Federal Government and the Democrats. My understanding is that every State of Australia is opposed to the legislation and, without exception, so is every business organisation of consequence.

One of the criticisms of the legislation is that it diminishes ministerial responsibility. I think it was Senator Tate who observed in a report from the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities some time ago that the Senate was having legislation recommended to it which it had not considered itself. If I am not wrong, that is how the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee got its terms of reference. Senator Tate nods in acknowledgment. If we are prepared, in a federal system, to embrace cooperative systems, there has to be some diminution of singular ministerial accountability, on an individual basis, but in a collective sense there is a gaining of ministerial responsibility. No doubt no decisions are made at the Ministerial Council that do not have majority support. Each Minister is required to enact legislation in his own Parliament for which he is personally responsible. That includes all the States and the Federal Parliament. I would have thought that that gave more strength to ministerial responsibility, not less.

However, under the proposed arrangements the Federal Government will assume all legislative responsibilities and the Ministerial Council from that day forth will be nothing more than an advisory body. All the powers and responsibilities of a legislative and administrative nature will be in Canberra. I can think of no worse place to provide for decisions that affect businesses. I can think of no more artificial or rarified atmosphere conducive to giving the worst decisions than Canberra. There is no place in Australia where decisions are made that is more removed from the real world than Canberra. Yet, with the typical arrogant audacity that is the hallmark of this Government, it has satisfied itself again that the way to solve problems, no matter how minute they may have been at the outset, is to centralise the decision making in one Commonwealth Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Senator McKiernan agrees. As a senator from Western Australia I am surprised, given that this legislation will have more detrimental effects, not only on government and on administration but also on business, in Western Australia than in almost any other State. Businesses in Western Australia will no longer have direct and immediate access to the decision makers. They will no longer be able to provide input, to offer advice or to have discussions with those who make the decisions, those who are party to the legislation. They will have to undertake the trek to Canberra to make a contribution to decisions that affect their businesses in an intimate way, in the same way that anybody from Western Australia who wants to solve a problem in the High Court of this country has to trek 3,500 miles to Canberra and back.
—Not all the time. The High Court goes to Perth.

—The High Court visits Western Australia two or three times a year, I think. That is a long time between drinks when one is waiting for a decision. The more remote States such as Western Australia and Tasmania will find themselves political eunuchs, no longer part of the decision making, no longer privy to the contemplation that is intended to reflect what is in the best interests of business. It seems to me that the only people who may imagine they will benefit from this legislation are the bigger businesses of this country. Yet I understand that the Business Council of Australia, on second reflection, has changed its mind and no longer supports the proposal in the way that it did from the outset.

SPEECH.PARA: One can go through the various organisations that are likely to be affected. They include the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges. It has indicated that in its view the existing cooperative scheme should be retained without substantial alteration. The Institute of Directors in Australia has submitted that the present system was viable and that it should be maintained. It has said that the present system testifies to the fact that there was a desire on the part of the governments concerned for both uniformity and cooperation. I would have thought that they would be at least two of the criteria for good, responsible, proper and sensitive legislation that reflects the concerns of business and shareholders in this country.

The Tasmanian Government considers that the scheme has provided the basis for sound administration in the area of commercial administration generally. The Western Australian Corporate Affairs Department judged that the present system had been `remarkably successful'. It specifically cited the uniformity that had been brought to the law. Mr Alan Smith, the Western Australian Commissioner for Corporate Affairs, said that he doubted whether the administrative problems encountered between the different officers in administering the present system would be fixed by a Commonwealth system. He said that if there was a complete Commonwealth takeover initiatives such as the second board market in Perth would simply not have got off the ground.

The second board was the brainchild of the Perth Stock Exchange and it received absolutely no support, help or assistance from the brokers in Sydney and Melbourne. So the Perth Stock Exchange went it alone. It went to the Western Australian Department, it set down its problems and the Department, in conjunction with the Perth Stock Exchange, worked through the problems. We now have a vibrant and effective second board that makes a substantial contribution, particularly to small and medium sized business in Western Australia. It gives an entry point for shareholders or for the people of Western Australia and Australia generally to invest in companies so listed. When asked about the question of costs and benefits and particularly about the surplus the Western Australian Department generated, Mr Smith said that there were revenues of about $14m-this is just in Western Australia-and expenditure of about $7m. Making an estimation of the costs of accommodation, computing and other costs which are not normally taken into account, he estimated a surplus of about $2m. So we see just one tangible example of the benefits.

I do not need to list all of those who support the present proposal. We know, of course, that the South Australian business community is supportive, as is the South Australian Government. We know that the Victorian Government is supportive. We know that the Victorian Attorney-General declared himself in evidence as a committed centralist who on first blush supported the proposed centralising of legislative responsibility and powers in Canberra but who on serious and deliberate reflection changed his mind and made it quite clear that there was no general support from the business community or his Government for the proposals which we have before us.

Yet the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), as he did with the referenda, intends to march on believing in what he is doing in the face of and in spite of overwhelming and unqualified objection and opposition to his legislation. This legislation is made up of 1,300 clauses and 3,000 pages. Rather than accepting Senator Hill's proposition of having that legislation examined from a philosophical, practical and principled point of view by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the narrow confines of the Democrats' proposal is simply to tinker with the edges and play with the mechanics. It in no material way challenges the legislation to see whether it has substance, weaknesses or faults, to see whether it works and perhaps most of all to see whether it has a constitutional basis, whether there is a head of power in the Constitution that allows the legislation in the first place.

It is not with any qualification that I support the proposals that are put by Senator Hill. It is with disappointment that I am required again to record the fact that the Democrats seem so obsessively committed to supporting the Government in what I would have thought was an unhealthy way. They are putting aside the interests of business, investment, State governments and individuals. They are simply supporting the Attorney-General, who managed to convince-as he did with the referendums-his Government, Cabinet and party room that there is some intrinsic virtue in this legislation when none can be found. This Government is hell-bent on convincing itself that it has some virtue when there is none to be had.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot find it; we can.

—The Democrats say they can find it. With respect, the honourable senator should rise to his feet and spend the next half hour convincing me what it is. Of course there is no intrinsic value to be found. We find that as a result of the support of the Democrats this legislation will pass; it will go off to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, which will no doubt report in the very narrow sectional sense and leave aside the material and important considerations which ought to be the cornerstone, the foundation and more than anything else the primary concern of the Committee in examining the legislation.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any citizens interested in this legislation and listening tonight will, after Senator Crichton-Browne's speech, be massively confused about what it is we are doing. I put it clearly that the Bills were introduced by the Government, and a motion moved for the second reading. Upon the speech of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) being incorporated I moved for the Bills essentially to go to a committee. It was not in fact the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs as Senator Crichton-Browne seems to think but rather a joint select committee. The off the cuff approach of Senator Crichton-Browne was illustrated through almost all of the remarks he made. Having obviously not read the legislation or the Minister's second reading speech and having not followed the various discussions and statements that the Minister has made over time, he was unable, for example, shuffling through his papers, even to understand which particular constitutional power the Commonwealth was drawing on. In fact it is not drawing on one but a range, as the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has stated time and time again.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne then reiterated the point that had been made by Senator Hill about the problems that would occur if this legislation was passed and there was a challenge. He obviously had not listened to Senator Tate's response. He had not read the Attorney-General's release of almost two months ago in which it was clearly stated that the Government would await a challenge in the High Court of Australia before the proclamation. It is illustrative of Senator Crichton-Browne's approach to the whole exercise. He shackles together a few bits of misinformation and whirls them around as though he is making a serious contribution to what is an important point.

I moved for this committee to be established. I raised the matter with the Attorney-General quite some time ago. It was interesting to note at that stage that the Opposition was conspicuous by its absence from the entire debate. Upon the announcement that we would have a committee inquiry-something which I would have thought would have been welcomed by the Opposition-a misleading letter from the shadow Minister in this area, the honourable member for Ryan, Mr John Moore was published in the Australian Financial Review. It was an excessively misleading letter, as I had the chance to point out in a response that I made in the same newspaper, because, amongst other outrageous, outlandish and unsupportable claims, it stated that we had threatened to block the legislation unless a committee was set up.

I think it is interesting that Mr Moore was not at the meeting, had never sought a meeting and, up to that stage, had not had a discussion with me, yet he was able to say what had happened at a meeting at which he was not present. I was able to declare quite clearly-there were a number of people at the meeting-that no such threats were made. I made the suggestion that it would be very useful to have such a committee to try to pick up some of the outstanding problems. The Attorney-General was very willing to accede to that suggestion. He thought it was a good idea. That was the type of meeting which was described as a sort of throwing down of the gauntlet.

I would have thought that members and senators might be able to contribute something more if this committee were set up, rather than for them-as tends to be the case, and as was shown again by Senator Crichton-Browne's speech-to engage in one of those exercises in which they have a shot at anybody who does not totally agree with them, putting aside the serious or important issues that are to be debated in this area. That is not unusual, and I suppose it is asking an awful lot that in today's political climate we should have a serious discussion of a serious proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, why not support Senator Hill's proposal?

—I would like to go through the points raised by Senator Hill in his amendment. I will take them one by one. In his first point he wants the committee to examine whether the Bills meet the legitimate needs of business-my terms of reference cover this point-all State governments and other interested groups within the community. I do not know whether the legislation will meet the legitimate needs of all State governments. In fact, I think it is highly unlikely that any piece of business legislation will meet the needs of all State governments. From the point of view of drafting, it is a pretty silly statement. From the point of view of an expression of opinion, it is even sillier. The terms of reference that I have put down will easily encompass the notion of looking at the legitimate needs of the business community. I believe that the committee inquiry will look at those needs and will seek views from the business community and from any others in the community who wish to put a proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph (b) of Senator Hill's amendment covers a more substantial point. He wants the committee to examine the Bills for unintended legal and commercial consequences, and report whether the passage of the Bills and the scheme thereby created is the only means of facilitating further national and international development of Australian business. I do not suppose that this is the only means. It would be a fairly extraordinary claim to make that this is the only way in which it can be done. I do not know anybody who would ever make those types of claims. This is assumed to be the best way in which it can be done.

I again make the point that I made when I put down the terms of reference; that is, that a legitimate political debate will take place in the Committee of the Whole and in the second reading debate when the legislation is returned from the committee inquiry. I do not believe that that is a legitimate area for committee inquiry. I say that because it would undoubtedly end up being an exercise in the production of a couple of reports. In fact, this point was exemplified by the speech made by Senator Crichton-Browne. I do not think that is of any use in terms of a committee inquiry. I hope that, in the development of our committee system, we will try to maintain the setting up of such committees in the areas in which they have been so productive to date. Undoubtedly, from time to time there will be majority and minority reports. But let us not specifically attempt to generate such an inquiry, because I believe that it will put off track what I see as a developing use of our committee system-a use to which I believe the Opposition parties are also committed. Whether a modified cooperative scheme could achieve such results is an area for legitimate political debate-one which I am sure we will have when we reach the Committee of the Whole stage.

Paragraph (c) of Senator Hill's amendment-whether an efficient regulatory system can be achieved by an alternative scheme-is a reiteration of paragraph (b). In so far as it seeks an efficient regulatory system, that is a judgment about whether this system is more or less efficient. Again, that political debate will take place in this chamber, as it should. Paragraph (d) refers to the interests of shareholders and the broader investor community. That is incorporated in my terms of reference.

Paragraph (e) refers to whether it is desirable and advisable to proceed with passage of the Bills considering the serious constitutional concerns. I would have thought that after hearing Senator Hill's speech nobody would want to raise that issue, because Senator Hill referred to a list of committees and various other groups which considered this issue and brought down conflicting opinions. I do not want to be unkind to the lawyers who may be present in the chamber. I cannot see too many of them; I can see the Minister, who is not listening at the moment, so he probably will not hear what I am about to say. I think that the number of lawyers who would get together would probably equal the number of opinions, plus one.

I do not really believe that yet another committee will settle the issue. There is only one way of settling the issue of the constitutional validity of this package of legislation-that is, by reference to the High Court. Unfortunately, we did not manage, for want of support, to get a constitutional change which would have allowed us to have an advisory opinion. Such an advisory opinion would have been very useful in this area. Of course, those people who are so enlightened as to attack any changes to the Constitution managed to get that proposal defeated as well. It would have been very useful for the Parliament to have asked the High Court for an advisory opinion on this matter and to have received that before we proceeded. I think it is a pity that we are not able to do so.

So, the Government has done the next best thing-that is, it has made a declaration that, upon the passage of this legislation by both Houses, it will await the constitutional challenge which will undoubtedly be made. Senator Crichton-Browne has already told us that all the State governments are opposed to it, so undoubtedly there will be a constitutional challenge. That is where a constitutional challenge will be settled. It really cannot be settled by yet another inquiry.

The gratuitous attack that the honourable senator made on an eminent lawyer who gave reference material to a previous Senate committee was most untoward. In fact, a previous speaker also attacked the same legal person. The types of statements which were made could certainly bring into play the motions which were passed by this chamber with regard to privilege. Indeed, if I were that person, I would seek to use those motions so that my side of the story was placed on the record. They were most unfair characterisations and attacks upon somebody who had provided material to a previous Senate committee inquiry. I believe that traducing such a person who was engaged in that activity is not helpful to our committee inquiries in any way, shape or form.

Paragraph (f) of Senator Hill's amendment has five parts. The first part deals with whether the passage of the Bills will result in a loss by State regulatory authorities. Fairly obviously, in a national scheme one would have that loss, but that is an administrative follow-through. I am not quite sure that, if there is one, there will not be the other. The third part of paragraph (f), which refers to a loss of skilled staff from State corporate affairs offices, and the fourth part, which refers to a loss of business and professional expertise in the States, are not necessarily consequences of the legislation. It depends on what type of constructive attitude-if the legislation is passed-the States take. The Attorney-General has indicated publicly on several occasions that there is adequate room for discussion between the Commonwealth and the States as to how this package of Bills might be administered. From time to time the Attorney-General held out the possibility, for example, of the close corporation being administered, a split administration, a devolution of administration, and a whole variety of methods. It does not follow from the legislation as to how they will be administered.

In previous discussions that I have had with Senator Hill I pointed out that the administration of these items is something separate from the legislation of these items. These legislative arrangements, if carried, will be legislation of the Commonwealth Parliament. The executive authority will vest in the Commonwealth government. The regulatory day to day control will vest in an independent commission. That is the type of structure that is being suggested in which I believe we will have a significant role to play-and not as Senator Crichton-Browne attempted to caricature, that somehow or other everybody will dash to Canberra. If anybody is going to dash anywhere I suggest that it be to Melbourne where the Securities Commission is, not to Canberra. If Senator Crichton-Browne had read the Bills he would know that that would not be necessary on almost all occasions. It would be somewhat less necessary in a whole host of areas in regard to business than is currently the case under the cooperative scheme. But then again, I do not assume from the honourable senator's comments that he has read the legislation.

The fifth part of paragraph (f), which relates to adequate funding, is dealt with in the terms of reference. So significant parts of Senator Hill's amendment are dealt with. Those parts that are not dealt with were quite explicitly excluded from my reference, as I said before, in an attempt, firstly, to maintain what I believe to be the thrust of where our inquiries are going by way of committee in this chamber-and hopefully in the other place although I know that its committees are nowhere near as effective as ours; and secondly, to ensure that this is a tightly focused inquiry that is of benefit to business. When the legislation comes back from that particular inquiry, we will have the second reading debate and the committee stage of the Bills in which the political points that Senator Crichton-Browne made can be argued and settled, as is the way in this chamber, by divisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you voting for any of them?

—We will not be voting for this package of Bills, and presumably neither will the honourable senator, on the basis that there are already recommended amendments. We support many of the amendments that have been recommended by the House of Representatives. We have particular views that I think will be accepted by the committee. Business has a number of views which I am sure will be accepted by the committee. I am sure that the committee of inquiry will find additional amendments that it will recommend which I hope will be accepted by the Government. The numbers in support of such amendments will be tested in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that is a reasonable proposition. It is not the caricature that has been presented but one which we put forward, after consideration of the Bills and after discussions with the industry and others in the regulatory environment across Australia, as a useful contribution to the development of this debate. It is not, I suppose, as politically hardened as Senator Crichton-Browne would like, but it was meant to be a significant contribution of this legislature to that exercise. In addition, I commented that I hope we will move after that to the establishment of a statutory committee which would have a continuing oversight of a package of national legislation. I believe that that would add immeasurably to the expertise one would find here and in the other place. As I said before, we strongly support the development of those statutory committees. It provides both chambers with a very good and very useful base upon which further decisions can be made, and a useful avenue for those people in business who are concerned about the legislation to voice opinions. They do not have to go to government, they will not have to go to the bureaucracy; they will be able to go, if they wish, to a committee of this Parliament, if a particular suggestion is taken up, which will comprise representatives of all political parties. That, I think, is the type of development taking place. Let us try to pursue that line. If we do, we will add lustre to the deliberations of this chamber and move it further away from what I see as the destructive elements in debates that take place in the House of Representatives. I believe this chamber has an excellent opportunity before it to make history, if it wishes to grasp it. I do not think it has it if it seeks simply to be a reiteration of the head kicking exercises that take place in the House of Representatives.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Cook) proposed:

That, when next the Order of the Day for the resumption of the debate on the motion for the second reading of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1988 is called on, General Business notice of motion No. 70, standing in the name of Senator Powell and relating to the establishment of a Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, be called on at the same time and, upon the motion being moved, the motion shall be considered together with the motion for the second reading of the Bill but shall be voted on separately after the question on the motion for the second reading has been determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal and National parties oppose this motion. We frankly do not understand why the Government is supporting a proposal to bring on this motion of Senator Powell's. This motion of Senator Powell's will create a Senate inquiry into farm chemical use in Australia in the widest possible terms. At present a number of those inquiries are being conducted. The first is an inquiry being conducted by the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC), the Government's own council. This is a council of very eminent people which is currently conducting an inquiry into chemical residues in agricultural products. The terms of reference of the inquiry are wide and I am advised that the Council believes that it will be able to report to the Government by December of this year.

SPEECH.PARA: It is our understanding that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has claimed that he only grudgingly supports the Australian Democrats' push for a Senate inquiry. He does not have to grudgingly support it at all. All the Government has to do at the present moment is to join with the Liberal and National parties and either throw out this proposed inquiry or, it it wishes, put a proposition to us that we defer it until after the ASTEC report is received. We could then debate the motion. We still would not be supporting it, but at least we could then debate it in the light of the ASTEC report. But no, the Government is actually assisting Senator Powell to bring this matter on for debate at this stage and to establish this Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia at this stage of the proceedings, when there is clearly no need for it because of the ASTEC inquiry.

But not only is ASTEC conducting its inquiry into this matter. There are subcommittees of the Australian Agricultural Council which are also conducting inquiries into chemical residues in agricultural products. All these inquiries are currently being conducted. Now the Senate is going to have imposed upon it a very wide ranging inquiry as proposed by the Democrats. I would firstly say to the Government that the costs of the proposed inquiry cannot be justified. Secondly, and much more importantly, because this inquiry proposed by Senator Powell is of such an open nature one must fear for the future of Australian primary produce. It is an inquiry that will deal with the economic, social and environmental impact on Australia of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their alternatives. That will mean that there will be opportunities for all sorts of people to come before that committee and give evidence about what is the environmental impact on Australia of chemicals in primary production. It may well be that somewhere along the line there needs to be some sort of general inquiry into chemical use around the world. But what is happening here is that the Australian Democrats, supported by the Government-indeed, encouraged and assisted by the Government-intend to put Australian primary production and Australian primary producers out on the line as the example for the rest of the world to consider whether any of our produce is affected by chemicals in a manner that may be detrimental, so that Australian produce will be the produce that will suffer.

The inquiry will not examine American produce, European produce or produce from other countries around the world. It will examine Australian produce. This has the potential to substantially affect our trading markets and the reputation of Australia's agricultural produce as being safe and of a premium quality. The proposal does not recognise the need for a speedy resolution of the problems of compensation and assistance to the quarantined farmers. If it were to look at those questions, there may be some merit in it. If this inquiry were to look at these farmers-and I understand that currently 1,119 farms in Australia are quarantined because of chemical residues-and to examine whether those farms or farmers on those farms were entitled to compensation and what sort of compensation they would be entitled to for the problems they have suffered, then one might see merit in it. But the motion is not in any way proposing to deal with that.

This inquiry could undoubtedly develop into a witch-hunt aimed at Australia's 55 chemical manufacturers. There are 55 chemical manufacturers in Australia, and let there be no doubt what the Australian Democrats will be on about with this committee of inquiry: they will be after the skin and blood of those chemical manufacturers.

Let me go a step further. Last year the Government's Business Regulation Review Unit recommended a system of self-regulation and opposed many features of draft legislation for the control of industrial chemicals. I point out to the Government that the objective of this Democrats proposal may be to reverse those recommendations of the Business Regulation Review Unit. It is hypocritical of the Government, on the one hand, to support this sort of witch-hunt that will go on as a result of this inquiry into the farm chemical industry and yet, on the other hand, to withdraw funding from a national survey of pesticide residues in food. I point out that at the national convention of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia Ltd, the Executive Director of that organisation, Mr Allen Morley, criticised the Federal Government's proposal to discontinue the annual market basket survey which he said was one of the few independent and credible surveys of pesticide residue levels in food in the world. What has happened is that the Government has withdrawn funding from that survey and now is enabling the Democrats to go on with this witch-hunt into the farm chemical industry.
There is massive opposition to this inquiry from industry sources. The National Farmers Federation, in a news release of 10 February this year, stated:

The National Farmers' Federation said today the Senate inquiry into agricultural and veterinary chemicals, proposed by the Australian Democrats, was unnecessary and would halt action already taking place.

The first time Allen Morley came to see me-indeed long before that, when I first took on the shadow portfolio of primary industries for the Australian Democrats-I said, `Look, Mr Morley, if you are so confident about what your industry is doing and what your products do, you should have no fear of appearing in a public forum to extol the virtues of your products and your industries'. I believe that is a perfectly valid argument. That is exactly what anybody would do in this context. We are saying in this inquiry proposal that everybody should have the opportunity, not just an industry which has a strong financial economic base-a multinational one at that. This opportunity should be available not just to well-funded Establishment rural organisations but also to consumers, people interested in alternatives, people with a story to tell, people with advice which can be useful to everybody and even, dare I say it, some scientists who diverge from what has been said to us for generations, the results of which we are now suffering not least in the beef industry, as we saw at the end of last year.

To show that the times have changed since the date of some of the quotes which were given to us by the Opposition, I will quote from the excellent rural newspaper, the National Farmer. The National Farmer moved from a position of considerable scepticism late last year and early this year to a particularly important editorial dated 26 August in which it said, among other things:
But this newspaper also believes it has a responsibility to inform farmers of what is going on about them, even if what is going on about them is not good news.

May I say, `Hear, hear'. That is exactly what the Senate has the responsibility to do and can do not just through this legislation before us but also through the broader and longer term approach of the proposed committee. The editorial went on to say-a point I have already made:

``Clean'' food will become an international trade issue as this century comes to a close, and Australia is in a prime position to take advantage of it because of our remoteness from the ``dirty'' environment of the Northern Hemisphere.
But to do so, we must demonstrate how ``clean'' we are again and again.
We must do this not just once, not just twice but again and again. It went on to say:
Part of that demonstration is jumping on any trouble-publicly . . .

Somehow or other the Opposition seems to disapprove of the public nature of what is being proposed here. `Let us keep the lid on it', is what Senator Archer said. The Australian Democrats laughed because that is exactly what has been happening for decades.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The point, of course, as you obviously understand, is that the question is: Why should these matters be debated cognately? If they are debated cognately, they will both be dealt with now. I am making the point that this is an issue of the moment. My notice of motion has been before the Senate for 10 months. We have been waiting for this legislation, which is totally related to my proposed motion-the subject matter is exactly the same-but which is a first step. Obviously, further steps need to be taken. The Democrats, along with the National Farmer newspaper, believe that those steps need to be open and comprehensive and need to be taken now. That is, of course, a major reason why this cognate debate needs to take place, and needs to take place now.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to point out that immediately after the Federal election in 1987 I publicly noted the very strong statements of both the new Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, and the new shadow Minister, Senator Puplick, that they believed that land degradation was the greatest environmental problem facing this nation. I instigated, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, an urgency debate in regard to which all parties in this chamber concurred. I draw attention to one of the terms of reference of the proposed committee. If we still believe that at the moment land degradation is one of the major issues before us, I suggest that those Opposition senators who clearly do not understand the problems of land degradation should read a paper by Professor Lovett of the Department of Agronomy and Soil Science at the University of New England. In terms of relativity between this legislation and the proposed motion, there can be no doubt that the advanced legislation which is now before us, courtesy of hard work by the Minister and relevant State authorities, is the first step. Many more steps are to be taken. Under the terms of reference we have proposed, those steps will be well under way. The responsibility of this Parliament, in leadership for the interests of the future of Australian agriculture and the Australian community in general, would be met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating-though one would doubt it, having listened to the previous speaker's contribution-whether to consider two matters cognately. Last Friday we debated the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill, which we support and which deals with standardising and expediting procedures by which agricultural and veterinary chemicals can be cleared for safe use in Australia. It wants to do away with the multi-testing system and revert to a system of a State taking responsibility for passing agricultural and veterinary chemicals for use among the industries. Once the chemicals have been cleared, they will be cleared for use throughout Australia, except Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that it is proposed that we debate cognately-I do not have a copy of it-is a proposed motion for a wide-ranging inquiry into veterinary chemicals and their use in Australia. The inquiry would be so wide-ranging that I do not understand why it would look at only veterinary and agricultural chemicals. Chemicals are used in mining, medicine and other areas. Why could there not have been a proposal for an open inquiry, instead of just lashing into the agricultural and veterinary chemical industries? Of course, the veterinary chemical industries are mainly dependent on the agricultural chemical industry. I know that a certain amount of work is done outside those industries. I refer, for example, to the horse racing industry. I direct my remarks to the veterinary area as it affects the agricultural industry. That industry is being bashed once again. The greenie and nut element in the other corner would like to bring the industry to its knees. Many governments over the years would have liked to keep the farmers as peasants. They have not quite succeeded in doing so, but they would if they could.

I return to the cognate debate proposal. What does one do with an important piece of legislation that is required to be brought on stream if some elements want to include something that is a bit unsavoury? This does not only occur here; it also occurs in the business world. If a person has one good deal to offer and one that is not so good, what does he do? He puts them together; he muddies the water. It is the same as giving a child his medicine. If he does not like it, give him a piece of chocolate to take away the bad taste. That is exactly what this rebel group is trying to do.

Last Friday certain arrangements were made that there would be no divisions. I respected that arrangement. It was made for a very good reason. The Australian Democrats have been crying out for their nutty inquiry since at least December last year. The Government had decided to back their proposal and not ours. Our proposal was very well defined. We proposed to look into the problems of pesticides in beef and the question of compensation. Incidentally, the Government was fairly interested in the proposal at the time, but for some reason the Government, so that it could get some legislation passed-I forget what it was-decided to back the Democrats' proposal and not ours. The proposal had been around for about 10 months and the Democrats were getting nowhere with it. They decided to attempt to introduce it by having a cognate debate with a piece of legislation for which Australia has been waiting for quite a while.

Senator Powell said that this legislation was introduced only because of the beef pesticides problem. That is a total lie. The legislation was proposed before the pesticides problem came about. As I said in my speech last Friday, detection of pesticides in beef only accelerated bringing it on-so that the chemicals could be registered much more quickly and tested far more widely, and tested overseas as well. The legislation had been lying there for a long time. The Government tried to sweeten up the wide-ranging inquiry by proposing to debate the matter cognately with a proposal by Senator Powell to establish a Senate committee of inquiry into agricultural and veterinary chemicals. If a government wants to get something passed when it is not so good all it has to do is put it with something sweet so it can be looked at through rose-coloured glasses. That failed last Friday, of course, because our Deputy Leader, Senator Lewis, refused to debate it cognately. That is the way to do it-muddy the waters. I had defined exactly the situation regarding this legislation. Now we have this smokescreen.

I return to my point about our inquiry and the Democrats' inquiry. When it came to the Government's notice last year, one member of the Government-and there is only one member on the other side of the chamber who can claim to have the authority to speak on agriculture--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is that?

—I will come to that in a minute. There is only one member of the Government on the other side of the chamber who can speak on agriculture and that is Senator Walsh-a wheat growing colleague of mine for the last 30 years in the eastern wheat belt of Western Australia.
—He deserted the farmers a long time ago.

—Perhaps he has got away from the farming scene a little, but he has enough nous to know what is going on. He got wind of it that there was going to be this nut cracking, wide-ranging debate. Unfortunately, I happened to run into him in a corridor in the old Parliament House, and he said, `What are you fools trying to do?'.
—Just outside the bar?

—No. Actually, I never found the bar in that place. He said, `You are trying to open up a wide-ranging debate. Anyone will be able to say what they like without any scientific backup'. As I said last Friday, there is nothing wrong with respected scientists putting their case to an inquiry. Respected scientists will be judged by their peers.
—Like Rachel Carson--

—Whoever that is, Senator Coulter. They will be judged by their peers. If they come up with stupid claims they will be taken for what they are. Nutty type people, people who are vindictive against farmers and veterinarians, can make whatever statements they like and get away with it, but the publicity, as Senator Archer pointed out, will be there. To return to Senator Walsh, that was the crack that he had at me. I said to him, `The story is that we are trying to get a Senate select committee going to look into the problems associated with the use of pesticides and how we can overcome them'. When he understood the fact that it was the Democrats and not us, he cooled off a little. Unfortunately, other members of the Government decided, for some reason or another, to go along with the Democrats' proposal.
—A bit of a deal, I think.

—It probably was a deal. Probably Senator Walsh was hoping that the Democrats would forget about it as time went by and that they would find a few other issues to run with from which they could pick up some publicity for their failing support, as the last few elections showed. Unfortunately, they remembered and tried to bring it on as a cognate debate, which is what we are debating now.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, we withdrew our proposition so that the rest of Australia could judge the Democrats on their merits. That is the present state of affairs. As we are debating whether to debate these matters cognately, the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) is conducting an inquiry. It is bound by its terms of reference to report by the end of the year. It will report on the use of agricultural chemicals and their effect on health, the environment, business regulations, et cetera. It is based on the premise that the quality of agricultural products with respect to chemical residues is likely to become a more important factor in the marketing of these products, particularly for export. That Council is very respected throughout Australia. It was charged some time ago with looking into this problem. Senator Archer incorporated a list of members of that Council. The Deputy Chairman is Lloyd Zampatti, an eminent Western Australian scientist probably known to Senator Coulter. The Council was charged to come up with a balanced scientific finding and to make recommendations and guidelines for the use of chemicals in agriculture. It is due to report at the end of the year. If this unfortunate motion were to go through and we did set up a wide-ranging, idiotic, nut cracking inquiry by 31 December-when ASTEC is bound to report-that Senate select committee would not even be in place. What confidence would we be showing in these eminent scientists if we were to do that? That is the reason. It is a total waste of time to debate whether we should debate this matter cognately.

This legislation is very necessary. As soon as the debate on this legislation is out of the road, we can put it into action. Yet here we are debating it with something that has no substance. The proposed committee would have wide-ranging terms of reference that probably Government members have not read. There is nothing solid or meaty about it. Why should we take another piece of legislation on board and refer it to a committee? It will be a wide-ranging inquiry that will achieve nothing. The proposed inquiry will be irrelevant. It is an inquiry to knock Australian agriculture, which supplies 50 per cent of Australia's income. A heap of greenies, obviously backed up by the Government, are trying to wreck the system. As I mentioned last Friday, we will be supporting the legislation. I foreshadowed that we will be moving amendments at the committee stage. We certainly will not be supporting this wide-ranging inquiry. We will be opposing it.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Thirty-third Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference-Violent Crime, Victoria

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m. the debate is interrupted. Under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday, 13 October the Presiding Officers tabled in the Senate a report of the Australian Delegation to the Thirty-third Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference at Kuala Lumpur. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would be aware that, traditionally, the report of the delegation to Commonwealth parliamentary conferences does not contain a detailed account of delegates' contributions to panel and plenary discussions, as a summary is usually contained in the journal The Parliamentarian. With respect to the Thirty-third Conference, this was published in the October edition for this year but, of course, it was only a summary.

SPEECH.PARA: The subjects discussed at the Conference are listed at pages 9 and 10 in the report tabled last week. However, I believe that in future years the report could be enhanced by including in it a summary of the contributions by members of the Australian delegation to the Conference. After all, there is a parliamentary secretary that attends with the Australian delegates and it would not be a big job to summarise the important contributions made by those delegates on future occasions. However, at present I believe that the contributions made at this Thirty-third Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference in Kuala Lumpur were of such significance that it may be of assistance to honourable senators if I outline briefly the major contributions of the main Australian participants.

In the discussion on cooperation by Commonwealth countries in facing the problems of adequate housing in the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless and what more can be done for refugees, a common suggestion was the channelling of help through a central Commonwealth agency. One Australian suggestion was for the establishment of a low interest loan scheme, investors earning inflation rate untaxed interest. The problems experienced by Australia were similar to those experienced overseas. The importance of motivation in the campaign to house the poor was stressed. Parliamentarians had a duty to raise the consciousness of governments and people. Local Commonwealth Parliamentary Association (CPA) branches were a means to make parliamentary colleagues aware of the need to deal with such poverty.

The topic `World Trade and Protectionism-The effect on world economic development in general and Third World economic, political and agricultural development in particular' led to endorsement of free trade and condemnation of restrictive practices by the European Economic Community, the United States of America and Japan. My contribution was to ask how can one be a good neighbour when one country deliberately takes trade, as it were, out of another's mouth. International trade was slowing and protectionism growing. The rich are getting richer both at domestic and international levels while the poor are getting poorer. Political bosses respond by expecting those who are being deprived to rise to the so-called `new challenges'. I warned that unless this relentless pursuit of protectionism as practiced on such a massive scale by mechanisms such as the common agricultural policy of Europe and similar effective actions by the United States and Japan ceased then not only would the tolerance of the Third World and middle countries be tested but also there would be a community reaction which would not be in the best interests of the brotherhood of nations. People will not forever stand back while living standards are in the best interests being eroded in the Third World.

I concluded that protectionism not only has important implications for declining living standards in the Third World but also has associated implications on the abilities of smaller and middle countries to service foreign debts. The deliberate dumping of overseas products on Third World markets upsets local infrastructure and farming practices. Immediate action was required on three fronts: halting farm subsidy increases; bringing about responsible management of stockpiles of surplus farm commodities; and reducing the gap between domestic prices for farm products and real market prices. I called on member countries to unite and be vocal against such unfair trade practices.

It is no consolation for people to shelter from the rain under, for example, the United States defence umbrella if at the same time they are being swept off their economic feet by a flood of United States protective devices. The meeting went on with the plenary sessions on `How best can Commonwealth countries cooperate to help contain the threat of AIDS?' and concluded that a Commonwealth pool of diagnostic, treatment and educational information should be established. One Australian delegate forecast an unbearable cost associated with AIDS, affecting many services outside health, if United Nations' predictions on the spread of the disease were correct. The World Health Organisation's containment program was supported, but the need to coordinate the flow of available information was stressed.

The fourth plenary discussion on `The role of television and the mass media in promoting respect for Parliament and an understanding of parliamentary democracy: Who is really responsible for the generally low image of the politician in the eyes of the public?' saw a division among CPA delegates as to how to apportion blame. One Australian contribution was to point generally to journalists' lack of understanding of a parliamentarian's daily work. Parliamentarians had a responsibility to set a high standard of personal behaviour, but the mass media also had a duty to present faithfully the work and role of parliamentarians.

The final plenary discussion on `Safeguarding human rights: The duty of the Commonwealth' led to spirited discussion, covering South Africa and the Eminent Persons Group, the work of Amnesty International and the advisory and information service run by the human rights unit of the Commonwealth Secretariat. The commitment to human rights was unanimous; there was some difference as to how to best enforce that commitment.

In panel discussions the main contributions by Commonwealth of Australia delegates were in panels B, D, E and F. Panel B's topic was `How should the House achieve greater accountability of the administration to Parliament: Is there a role for Parliament in the scrutiny of intelligence and defence activities?'. While recognising that sensitivity was necessary in some areas, the panel's participants generally felt that there was a need for parliament to exercise effective scrutiny of all the administration's activities. The panel was advised of some difficulties that have arisen in Australia because of crown or executive privilege, but that confidential information was made available to party leaders and some senior Ministers.

Panel D examined the topic `The role of the Commonwealth in contributions to world peace and combating terrorism'. The Australian contribution was to point to the Commonwealth's working for world peace and collective action in forming peacekeeping forces that could contribute to containing conflicts. In relation to terrorism, successive statements by Commonwealth Heads of Government had pointed the way, for example, to implement legal action against terrorists.

It was suggested by a member of our delegation that the topic considered by panel E, `The effect of continued population growth on the environment, unemployment and urban poverty within Commonwealth countries-Possible remedies', was an extremely difficult one which should be further discussed at future conferences. Panel F's discussion on `Planning Commonwealth co-operation in national projects to help overcome food shortages, for instance by irrigation of vast arid areas' resulted in support for a proposal for a common market of the Commonwealth for food grains and a more coordinated Commonwealth response in providing technological assistance, information exchange and human resource development to combat food shortages, setting up a special Commonwealth task force for this purpose.

Our contribution was to observe that the practice of certain rich industrialised countries in subsidising agricultural exports had diminished food for Third World countries that had to expand exports to buy food. It was suggested that Commonwealth national groups should concentrate on the question of finance and set up a suitable Commonwealth funding arrangement.

Mr President, I commend the standard of debates, particularly the Australian contribution. I thank our Malaysian hosts and my colleagues from the Commonwealth of Australia Branch, including you, Mr President, for making this conference a successful interchange of ideas on a legislator to legislator basis from Commonwealth parliamentarians. I reiterate the plea that I made initially, that the Australian contributions be summarised and included in the future reports of delegations to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conferences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As members of the Senate will be aware, on 12 October Constable Eyre from Shepparton and Constable Tynan from Glen Waverley were slain in the course of their duty at Walsh Street, South Yarra. They were laid to rest this week with tributes from family, friends and the Victoria Police Force. As a senator for Victoria, I pay tribute to these two young men for the contributions they made to public service in the State of Victoria. Victorians owe so much to these young men and to every man and woman who enters the police force with belief in the ideal to uphold the law for the protection of every citizen. To the bearers of this torch of protection we owe our personal safety.

SPEECH.PARA: It is then worth reflecting upon the murders and massacres of the past two years in Victoria and the deteriorating state of the personal safety of Victorians. If a starting point can be found, it is the Russell Street car bombing. I recall then writing, as a Melbourne city councillor, to the Melbourne Herald to express my views. Sadly those views still ring true today in the aftermath of the Hoddle Street, Queen Street and Walsh Street slayings. I said then:
This senseless act of violence should make us realise that terrorism is now a local issue, confronting the people of Melbourne.

The citizens best response to terrorism is to give their confidence and support to the institutions such as the Police Force and the Law Courts that protect us, and condemn those so frequently wishing to attack them.
Following the Walsh Street slayings, the Victorian Chief Commissioner of Police, Kel Glare, spoke in a very similar vein. He said:
The brutal murder of two policemen was a result of permissive attitudes which have eroded respect for police.
I think we are reaping the results of the permissive society of the 60's and 70's and respect for all institutions has diminished.

I believe the fundamental responsibility for laying a foundation of respect for law and order rests with governments. Governments have the power and the mandate to build a structure in which the citizens of the state can expect basic safety at home and at work. It is clear that Victorians are not receiving the leadership required in this area. The Victorian Government, by failing to boost police powers to deal with the growing crime rate, has contributed to the decline in respect for police authority. It is no secret that the relationship between the State Government and the police force is at best strained and at worst open hostility. The Government's unwillingness to give the required powers to the police is a fair indication that it does not trust the police. This clearly reverberates in society. As a result, police lose respect and authority in society.

It should also be remembered that in these times of violence it is not necessary just to re-establish the authority of the police force to deal with hardened criminals; there is a need to re-establish the most basic respect for human life. The State Government of Victoria has sadly failed in this arena also. It has in every way promoted bizarre embryo experimentation; unchecked abortions; euthanasia; and X-rated videos. It has been said that, if respect is lost for any stage or any part of human life, invariably respect will be lost for human life in its entirety. As I pointed out to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in this place today, the formation of yet another committee of inquiry into violence in our society is solely a means by which to delay and often avoid making the real and necessary decisions-that is, to establish total respect for human life enforced with the proper powers of both the police force and the law courts. I believe time has run out for talk, and genuine action is required. I further believe time has run out for the newly elected Victorian Government. Substantial action is needed. Surely it is true that Victorians cannot take another mass slaying.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 25 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to recent statements from the Minister regarding the labelling of artificial sweeteners, has the Minister received any further representations from manufacturers or merchants of artificial sweeteners; if so, what was the result, and can the Minister ensure that the word `artificial' will remain compulsory in the labelling of every product that does not directly emanate from sugar or from honey.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I have not received any representations on the labelling of artificial sweeteners since my statement on 21 July 1988 where I stated that the use of the term `artificial' to describe certain sweeteners would remain.

I understand that the National Health and Medical Research Council's Food Standards Committee have considered the matter in detail. The Council decided that the term ``artificial'' should continue to apply to chemically synthesised sweeteners in order that they are able to be distinguished from sugar, honey and related products. I have accepted the Council's advice on this matter.

I believe that consumers should have that basic information to enable them to make choices about the foods they consume, and the people who cannot consume those products for health reasons should be protected.

The final decision on whether the word `artificial' is to remain is a matter for the National Food Standards Council, the Commonwealth/State/Territory Committee of Ministers responsible for food legislation. I will be strongly urging this Council to retain the use of the term `artificial'.

I understand that the Australian Food Standards Committee, which comprises representatives from each State/Territory Department of Health, industry, consumers and professionals, amongst others, will keep the issue under review.

It would be pre-emptive of the National Food Standards Council meeting for me to give an assurance that the term `artificial' will be retained. I can, however, provide my own assurance that the Federal Government's position to retain it will not be changed, and that it will be strongly advocated by myself at all levels of the debate.
